content.rendered:
(The) Open Culture Foundation (OCF) is a non-profit organization. Through promoting open technology and cross-field collaboration, we continue to connect tech communities and other public and private entities in Taiwan. By doing so, we work to promote open co-creation and protect digital human rights, and thereby support a more transparent and inclusive digital civil society. Since 2014, we have functioned as a legal entity and supported over 30 open technology communities in Taiwan. Throughout this process, we have not only continued to promote the idea of open technology, we have also become involved in policy advocacy and spoken up for the public’s digital human rights. Through this process, we have created a base for the development of open technology in Taiwan. None of these successes are the result of OCF alone. Rather, they are the result of several open tech communities, individuals and organizations working together to make Taiwan’s internet and digital environment more open, transparent, and participatory.

開放文化基金會（Open Culture Foundation，簡稱 OCF）是一個非營利性的組織。透過推廣開放科技和跨界合作，在台灣持續的銜繫科技社群與其他公／私領域，來促成開放共創保障數位人權、支持透明涵融的數位公民社會。

自 2014 年創立以來，我們以法人做為組織形式，支持台灣 30 多個開放科技社群，在過程中，不僅是持續性的推廣開放科技概念，我們也開始參與政策倡議，為眾人的數位人權發聲，進而創建了一個在台灣發展開放科技的基地。這些成果並非由開放文化基金會獨立實現，而是透過科技社群和公民夥伴一起促使台灣的數位/網路環境變得更加公開、透明和公眾參與 — 不論這樣的參與是以個人、社群或是組織為名義。

We are so excited to see you soon for WordCamp Asia 2024 in Taipei, Taiwan. The organizing team is working hard to make it as comfortable, welcoming, and accessible as possible for all attendees. Here’s the latest info on the venue to help you plan your stay. Check back often for more details as we’ll confirm additional details on what you should expect when you arrive at Taipei International Convention Center (TICC).

About the Venue

WordCamp Asia will take place on multiple levels at the Taipei International Convention Center (TICC). The South entrance of the Taipei International Convention Center features a welcome driveway and barrier-free access ramp. There are a breastfeeding room, a diaper change table, an infirmary, AEDs, complimentary wheelchair rental, and mobile phone & electric wheelchair charging stations located in the building. Maps and signage around the venue will be provided to help you get around TICC. 

Check out the venue in 3D

WordCamp Asia Event Details

Programming

All speaker presentations are situated in four rooms, including Plenary Hall (Track 1), room 102 (Track 2), room 101B (Track 3), and room 101C (Track 4). During WordCamp Asia 2024, we’ll provide ramps in 101B and the Plenary Hall stages and work with venue staff to ensure wide aisles in all event areas for our motorized devices or wheelchair users, and priority seating. 

WordCamp Asia offers Wordly captioning services that will allow you to directly access captions in 57 languages in real-time from your mobile phone or laptop to supplement those displayed on stage. 

Meals and Special Dietary Concerns

During lunch, we’ll provide a variety of meals to meet your special dietary concerns including allergies, vegetarian, Kosher, or Halal. Lunch will be served in an individual bento box in the Banquet hall on the third floor, with volunteers available to assist. Please contact us with any questions or concerns you may have. 

Quiet and Family Rooms

If you need a break from the hustle and bustle of WordCamp Asia, we provide a quiet room. And if you bring your children with you, the family room is the place for you to hang out and rest. They are both located on the second floor. 

Lactation Room

Anyone who needs a private space for breastfeeding or pumping, please reach out to our volunteers, and we will guide you to the lactation room. 

Prayer Room (Male / Female)  

There’s a Muslim prayer room located on the middle floor close to room 101C. 

Muslim-Friendly information

COVID and Health Guide

According to the travel advice for Taiwan from the US government, it’s currently safe to travel with normal precautions (Level 1). You won’t need to go through rapid health checks or show vaccine records at the airport. However, we still recommend being careful for everyone’s safety. If you have symptoms such as coughing, fever, or sneezing, please consider not coming to the event. We encourage you to be masked while indoors. Additionally, it’s advisable to carry any personal medication you may need and consider getting vaccinated before your trip.

In line with guidelines from the CDC, WHO, and local health authorities, WordCamp Asia won’t require masks or COVID-19 vaccinations.

Need Assistance?

WCAsia staff will be available to assist you during the event. Look for them in black and royal blue T-shirts. For accessibility assistance, you can ask a volunteer, or go to the Information Desk located next to the registration.

If you have a Code of Conduct concern, you are also welcome to reach out via this contact form. A member of the WordCamp Asia Incident Response team will follow up.

If you have questions or need assistance regarding your accommodations at the venue, contact TICC at +886-2-2725-5200.

As the heart and soul of WordCamp, our volunteers play a crucial role in creating a welcoming and smooth experience for everyone involved. This year, as we gear up for our flagship event in the region, we’re looking for passionate individuals who want to make a difference and ensure the event’s success.

We extend our heartfelt thanks to all our volunteers who are gearing up for WordCamp Asia 2024. Your dedication and efforts are what make this event possible. At WordCamp Asia 2024, we understand that innovation thrives in a family-inclusive environment. That’s why we’re excited to welcome tech enthusiasts of all ages to our vibrant event!

Family-Friendly Room: Your Go-To Spot for Family Fun

Discover our specially designed Family-Friendly Room, a peaceful retreat within the bustling atmosphere of WordCamp. This dedicated space caters to the needs of families, offering a comfortable and engaging environment for attendees with children. We’ve set up the perfect spot for families, featuring engaging activities like Wapuus drawing canvases, an assortment of board games, and a collection of children’s books. It’s a comfortable and stimulating space where your kids can play, learn, and explore while you enjoy the event. Join us and make your family’s experience at WordCamp Asia 2024 both educational and enjoyable!

To Parents: You are responsible for your children’s children’s safety and health. Please stay with your children all the time. If you need assistance, please visit the Help Desk.

Free Children’s Tickets: Empowering the Next Generation

In our commitment to fostering a love for technology in younger generations, WordCamp Asia 2024 proudly offers free admission for children under 12. It’s our way of encouraging families to explore the future of technology together, without any additional cost. Dive into an immersive experience where learning, sharing, and innovation come alive for every family member!

WordCamp Asia 2024 Overview

WordCamp Asia 2024, a flagship WordCamp and the premier open source web summit of Asia, will be the ultimate gathering of around 2,000 WordPress enthusiasts from over 70 countries. It will be held at the Taipei International Convention Center (TICC) from March 7th to 9th, 2024. 

This year we’ve gathered: 

  • 38 Sponsors 
  • 56 Speakers
  • 47 organizers 
  • 500 contributors on the Contributor Day 

WordCamp Asia 2024 is a celebration of the vibrant WordPress community from Asia and beyond. It is a unique platform that highlights the diversity, inclusivity and spirit of the open source community across the globe focused on both using and advancing WordPress.

Over the course of the three days, there will be a diverse array of programs, workshops, and presentations, where industry experts will share their wisdom, and cutting-edge trends will be unveiled. Embrace the spirit of collaboration and giving back during the dedicated Contributor Day, where you can contribute to the WordPress project and make a lasting impact. 

In addition to these enriching interactions and opportunities to expand your knowledge and network, you’ll get to experience the beauty of Taipei. Soak in the rich culture, tantalizing cuisine, and awe-inspiring sights that this dynamic city offers. Our after-party will be a chance to make new friends and create lasting memories!

Note: For our media partners, please contact communications team for more details if needed.

Press Enquiries

If you have any questions regarding WordCamp Asia 2024, please contact us at asia@wordcamp.org or one of the members of the Communications Team.

title.rendered: A Journey Through Taipei’s Bubble Tea Wonderland: From Origins to Modern Delights

content.rendered:
Taipei, the vibrant capital of Taiwan, is renowned as the birthplace of bubble tea, a globally beloved beverage that has taken the world by storm. Embarking on a bubble tea trip in Taipei is like diving into a sweet and refreshing adventure – exploring the roots of this iconic drink and savoring the diverse modern variations that have emerged.

Here’s a list our highlights for a bubble tea trip in Taipei.

Chun Shui Tang

Our journey begins with a homage to the origins of bubble tea, which traces back to the 1980s in Taichung. The inventor, Lin Hsiu Hui, was working at a teahouse when she decided to experiment with adding sweetened tapioca pearls to traditional milk tea. The result was a delightful concoction that combined the rich flavors of tea with the chewy texture of pearls.

Visiting the site of the first bubble tea creation is a must for any enthusiast. Chun Shui Tang Teahouse, located in Taipei, proudly claims the title of the birthplace of bubble tea. Stepping into this historic teahouse feels like a step back in time, offering a nostalgic atmosphere where the magic of bubble tea first unfolded.

Xin Fun Tang

Xing Fu Tang, one of Taipei’s popular bubble tea chains, is renowned for its signature ‘stir-fried brown sugar pearls’. This innovative preparation method enhances the pearls’ aroma, creating a distinct caramelized flavor that sets it apart from other varieties.

For those seeking a more contemporary experience, The Alley is a stylish bubble tea shop that emphasizes aesthetics as much as taste. Their handcrafted drinks, featuring fresh and high-quality ingredients, have become Instagram sensations, making the experience as visually pleasing as it is delicious.

50 Lan

Founded in 1994, 50lan (also known as 50嵐) has played a pivotal role in popularizing bubble tea not only in Taipei but across Taiwan. Known for its dedication to using high-quality ingredients, 50lan has become a staple for locals and visitors alike. The name “50lan” translates to “50 orchards,” reflecting the brand’s commitment to using fresh and natural flavors.

The menu at 50lan offers a wide array of choices, ranging from classic milk teas to innovative fruit-infused concoctions. One of their signature drinks is the Honeydew Pearl Milk Tea, a refreshing blend of honeydew flavor and chewy tapioca pearls. The franchise’s success lies not only in its flavors but also in its consistent commitment to excellence.

Comebuy

Established in 2002, Comebuy has rapidly expanded its presence globally, making it a recognizable name for bubble tea enthusiasts around the world. With a focus on providing diverse options and a modern ambiance, Comebuy caters to a broad audience. The brand’s commitment to innovation is evident in its seasonal menu offerings, ensuring customers always have something new to explore.

Comebuy’s popularity lies in its ability to strike a balance between tradition and modernity. While offering the classic milk teas that patrons love, the franchise also embraces new trends, introducing creative combinations and toppings to keep the bubble tea experience exciting.

Guiji

Guiji means fruit in Taiwanese. Their fruit drinks are their signature. Lemon or grapefruit are fresh, and star fruits are pickled, yet sour. Guiji, Taiwan’s premier bubble tea and fruit tea brand, is renowned for its unique fruit-infused teas and high-quality ingredients.

Besides the five mentioned above, Taiwan has many more bubble tea shops offering different selections, such as Kebuke, Woo Tea, Milksha (you can directly search for ‘bubble tea’ or ‘珍珠奶茶/波霸奶茶’ on the map to find more!) Some integrate unique flavors from local features, while others bring a novel experience to drinkers through innovative methods, waiting for you to discover and share with us!

A bubble tea trip through Taipei is a delightful excursion for anyone seeking to unravel the history, savor the traditional, and relish the contemporary interpretations of this beloved beverage. From the humble beginnings at Chun Shui Tang Teahouse to the trendy offerings of modern tea shops, Taipei remains the ultimate destination for bubble tea enthusiasts.

Contributor Day at WordCamp Asia is about to get even more enriching with the introduction of the Human Library concept. This innovative addition aims to provide attendees with personalized interactions, allowing them to engage in one-on-one sessions with experienced contributors, referred to as “books.”

Defining the Purpose of the CD Human Library:

The primary objective of the CD Human Library is to offer attendees a unique opportunity to connect with expert contributors on a personal level. These “books” are dedicated volunteers eager to share their knowledge and insights, creating an environment conducive to meaningful conversations.

Recruiting Volunteer “Books”:

To ensure the success of the CD Human Library, proficient contributors, speakers, and WordPress experts from our community will be invited to participate as “books.” The voluntary nature of their involvement will be emphasized, underlining the value they bring to the event through sharing their expertise and experiences.

Implementing a Sign-Up System:

To streamline the process, a user-friendly sign-up system will be created, allowing attendees to register for one-on-one sessions with their preferred “books.” Clear communication regarding the approximate duration of each session, typically around 15-20 minutes, will be provided, encouraging participants to secure their time slots promptly.

Executing the CD Human Library Sessions:

A dedicated space during Contributor Day will be designated for Human Library sessions. An organized system will be put in place to manage session times and book availability, fostering a respectful and productive environment for meaningful conversations between participants and “books.”

Guidelines for a Positive Experience:

  1. Respectful Engagement:
    Participants are expected to engage in a respectful manner. Treat “books” with courtesy and appreciation for their voluntary contributions.
  2. Code of Conduct Adherence:
    All interactions must adhere to the Code of Conduct. Inappropriate or disrespectful behavior will not be tolerated.
  3. Mindful Questions:
    Attendees are encouraged to ask thoughtful and relevant questions that align with the purpose of the Human Library. Avoid asking questions that may be considered intrusive or inappropriate.
  4. Consent and Comfort:
    “Books” are not obligated to answer questions they are uncomfortable with. Respect their boundaries and be understanding if certain topics are off-limits.
  5. Time Management:
    Attendees should be mindful of the allocated session duration. Use the time efficiently to ensure that everyone has an opportunity to benefit from the Human Library experience.

After Contributor Day, feedback from both participants and “books” will be collected. This feedback will be carefully analyzed to assess the success of the Human Library concept and identify areas for improvement. Continuous refinement will ensure that future events feature an enhanced experience for all involved.

The Contributor Day Human Library is set to revolutionize the way attendees engage with the Contributor Day event. By providing personalized interactions and access to knowledgeable contributors, this initiative aims to empower participants, foster meaningful connections, and contribute to the overall success of WordCamp Asia. Get ready to immerse yourself in a truly enriching experience at the CD Human Library – where knowledge meets connection, and respect guides every interaction.

Exploring a metropolis like Taipei on foot is an excellent approach, particularly for first-time visitors. Walking tours offer a chance to familiarize oneself with the city’s layout, forge new connections, and gain insights into its culture and history through the eyes of the locals.

Taipei Golden Age Free Walking Tour

⏳ Duration: 2 h 30 min

Strolling through the old streets of Dadaocheng, particularly Dihua Street, tourists can explore well-preserved historical buildings, traditional medicinal herb shops, and handicraft stores. This area is a perfect destination to experience the early commercial and cultural essence of Taipei. Ideal for a leisurely walk, Dadaocheng whisks you back in time, offering a glimpse into the city’s rich past and vibrant present. It’s a must-visit for those looking to immerse themselves in the authentic charm of Taipei.

FreeTour: Taipei Golden Age Free Walking Tour

Klook: Taipei Free Walking Tour Golden Age Route

Taiwan Cultural Free Walking Tour

⏳ Duration: 2 h 15 min

Step into the heart of Taipei’s history at the venerable Longshan Temple, a cultural gem that has stood for over three centuries in the city’s oldest neighborhood. Experience the soul of Taipei as you wander through this sacred site, delving into the rich tapestry of Taiwanese traditions, the fascinating stories of local deities, and their profound influence on the Taiwanese people.

Embark on a journey through Taiwan’s cultural heritage and historical evolution. Explore the ancient practices of our forebears, their ingenious ways of healing without modern medicine, and their enduring spiritual beliefs. Longshan Temple, adorned with vibrant dragons, is a sanctuary for over a hundred folk deities, guardians of everything from maritime safety to victorious warfare. Connect with deities like Wenchang Dijun, the patron of scholars, or the Old Man Under the Moon, the matchmaker of legends. Our expert guide will introduce you to the art of casting ‘moonstones’ to seek divine guidance and interpret celestial signs. Receive a personalized fortune reading, learn about the temple’s storied past, and discover the intertwined paths of Buddhism and Taoism that have shaped this spiritual haven for generations.

Perfect for travelers seeking a deeper understanding of Taipei’s spiritual landscape, Longshan Temple offers a window into the city’s soul, inviting you to partake in timeless traditions and connect with the spiritual heritage of Taiwan.

FreeTour: Taipei Historic Free Walking Tour

Klook: Taipei Free Walking Tour Historic Route

Taipei’s Old Town

⏳ Duration: 2 h 15 min

Explore the essence of Taipei, Taiwan, on an enlightening tour that takes you through the heart of its history and culture. From the old town’s ancient narratives to the modern day, see how the past has intricately woven into the fabric of what Taiwan is today.

Curious about the foreign influences that have shaped Taiwan’s history? Intrigued by the poignant events of the 228 Incident? Eager to understand the remarkable transformation of Taiwan into its contemporary form? Our tour delves deep into these questions, providing a comprehensive look at Taiwan’s historical journey, its political evolution, and its rich cultural tapestry.

This complimentary walking tour navigates the historic streets of Taipei, taking you to significant locations like the 228 Peace Memorial Park, the Presidential Office Building, the Inner City Market, Zhongshan Hall, Ximending, and the Red House. Led by passionate and knowledgeable guides, you will explore not just the famous landmarks but also the city’s hidden treasures. This tour promises an engaging, enlightening, and memorable journey through Taipei’s storied past and vibrant present.

FreeTour: Taipei Old Town – Free Taiwan Introduction Tour

Taipei Historic Free Walking Tour

⏳ Duration: 3 hours

Taipei’s western district, a historical hub, once buzzed with the city’s foremost political and economic activities, marking the birthplace of its modern development.

Embark on a journey through time in this tour, tracing the evolution of Taiwanese history. From the traditional beliefs prevalent during the late Qing dynasty, through the cultural transformations under Japanese occupation, to the reshaped political landscape post-1949 with the arrival of the Nationalist government.

This Historic Tour encompasses all the key sites in Western Taipei, delving into the rich stories and legends that accompany each landmark.

As you traverse from historical eras to the present day, witness the unique blend of diverse cultures and pivotal events that have sculpturally molded Taipei. Gain a comprehensive understanding of this remarkable city and its multifaceted identity.

Klook: Taipei Free Walking Tour Historic Route

FreeTour: Taipei Golden Age Free Walking Tour

Morning Tour:Discover Taipei’s 100 Years of Glory

⏳ Duration: 6 hours

Discover the heart of Taipei in a single, captivating journey that takes you through its cultural and historical landmarks.

Marvel at the grandeur of the National Chiang Kai-Shek Memorial Hall, a symbol of Taiwan’s history and architecture. Find tranquility and architectural beauty at the historic Lungshan Temple, a serene retreat amidst the city’s bustle. Then, immerse yourself in the vibrant urban life of Yongkang Street, celebrated by Time Out as one of the world’s coolest streets, bustling with trendy cafes, shops, and culinary delights. 

This tour encapsulates the essence of Taipei, blending its rich heritage with a lively contemporary spirit.

Free Tour Half Day: Morning Tour:Discover Taipei’s 100 Years of Glory

Gourmet Guided Tour with Night Market

⏳ Duration: 6 hours

Experience the highlights of Taipei in a captivating tour that showcases the city’s diversity. Start with breathtaking views from the 32nd floor of New Taipei City Hall, offering a panoramic night vista of the city. Then, delve into history at the century-old Jieyun Temple, admiring its intricate architecture and serene atmosphere.

Cap off your adventure with the lively Nanya Night Market, a hub of delicious street food and bustling shopping, embodying the vibrant spirit of Taipei. This tour is a perfect blend of awe-inspiring scenery, cultural richness, and urban excitement.

Free Tour Half Day: Evening Tour:Gourmet Guided Tour with Night Market

title.rendered: 9 Useful Apps in Taiwan You Need to Know

content.rendered:
With WordCamp Asia 2024 just a few weeks away, we know you’re already planning on how to make the most of your visit to Taipei. To help you navigate the city and take advantage of what this incredible city has to offer, we’ve pulled together a list of Apps to download during your stay. 

Go! Taipei Metro

Want to discover local hotspots like the many night markets that Taipei is famed for? The city’s Metro system has you covered. 

The Go! Taipei Metro App provides a complete route map of the Taipei Metro system, which includes station exit information, train timetables, bus transfers, parking lots, and even nearby YouBike stations to help you travel more easily. Another great feature is the journey planner, which helps you calculate the fastest route to your destination.

iOS | Android

Uber

Uber is offers an easy-to-use and dependable ride-booking service, simplifying travel across the country. In cities like Taipei and beyond, Uber is an excellent choice for those unfamiliar with the local language or public transport. The app allows you to effortlessly book rides, monitor their driver’s whereabouts, and handle payments electronically, bypassing any language challenges and negating the need to negotiate fares with taxi drivers.

iOS | Android

Yoxi


After highlighting Uber’s user-friendly and reliable service, it’s worth mentioning Yoxi, another valuable app for travelers in Taiwan. Yoxi offers a similar ride-booking experience, tailored more towards local preferences. The app is straightforward, allowing easy booking and real-time driver tracking. With clear pricing and electronic payment options, Yoxi simplifies travel, especially for those unfamiliar with the local language or seeking to explore beyond major cities like Taipei.

iOS | Android

YouBike 2.0

What better way to discover the city of Taipei than by bicycle? 

YouBike 2.0 allows you to rent bicycles in every corner of Taipei. The app has an interactive map that makes it easy to find bike stations near you, and see how many bikes are available at each station. You can also view rental information and rates. 

You will need to register at the rental site to rent a bike. Please make sure you have an EasyCard and a Taiwanese mobile phone number to do this. Otherwise, you will need a credit card. 

iOS | Android

FunNow

There are many interesting experiences and food found all throughout Taipei—available at just the push of a button.

FunNow is a popular app that lets you book restaurants, massages, and other activities with just a click. FunNow offers low prices, quality service, and carefully selected locations. 

iOS | Android

KKday

Got a day of down time in between the WordCamp Asia program? KKday is an e-commerce travel platform that assists travelers in finding and booking local tours, activities, attractions, experiences and transportation.

Just enter your budget and time frame and KKDay will show you the best activities and attractions. You can instantly view description, price, duration and reviews. If you’re interested in attending an event, simply add it to your cart and proceed to checkout.

iOS | Android

Klook

If you have a day of downtime during the WordCamp Asia program and are exploring options beyond KKday, consider Klook as an alternative. Klook is another excellent e-commerce travel platform that offers similar services to KKday but stands out with its unique features. Especially friendly for international travelers, Klook provides access to local tours, activities, attractions, experiences, and transportation options.

iOS | Android

Taiwan Railway

If you’re planning on traveling further afield, look no further than the high-speed rail and Taiwan Railway.

The Taiwan Railway app helps you check timetables, train numbers, delays, travel times and fares. The app is very easy to use, but you need to know exactly where you are starting from and which station you are going to. Luckily, the answer can be found quickly with the help of Google Maps. Once you have accurate destination information, enter the app and select your departure and arrival stations and travel dates. All trains running on that particular day will pop up, showing their number, duration and cost.

iOS | Android

T-Express

In addition to Taiwan Railway, you have a faster option—the high-speed rail

Key features of the app include viewing timetables and fares, making instant payments, cancellations or modifications. Another great feature is that you have the option to get your mobile tickets by simply scanning them at the gate.

iOS | Android

Taiwan is an amazing place to travel, and using the apps above will help you easily explore the city, mingle with the locals, and enjoy your trip!

content.rendered:
To celebrate this year’s WordCamp Asia 2024. Join us for an awesome evening in Taipei, with the vibrant energy of Taiwan and Taipei, with the bloom of spring, and of course, three days of good vibes. While we celebrate the fusion of technology and spring’s renewal, we are marking WordPress’s latest revitalization into her 21st year, a perfect reflection of Spring’s essence. This afterparty will highlight the beautiful interplay between digital innovation and natural rebirth. Embrace this season of new beginnings and technological advancements with us. Don’t miss out on an event that promises to be as refreshing as the season itself!

This year, at the location MAJI MAJI we bring you six different areas with six unique vibes, a variety of food and drinks to enjoy — a party for all! Taking place at the former Flora Expo, it provides the perfect setting for this fusion of Spring celebration. Come join us at the WordCamp Asia 2024 after party where connections are made, ideas spark, and joy brings us together.

⏰ Date & time: March 9, 2024 (Sat.)  19:00~24:00

📍 Location: MAJI MAJI (Address: No. 1, Yumen St, Zhongshan District, Taipei City, 10491 (MRT Station: Red Line Yuanshan Station)

🧚‍♀️ Dress code: Casual, family safe but we’d love for you to dress up for the theme!

All you need is a ticket to WordCamp Asia 2024, and you’ll be on the guest list. 

Please note that the last Metro train bound for Taipei 101 station leaves Yuanshan Station at 00:34. If you miss this train, you will have to take an Uber or a taxi.

Make new connections

The After Party brings together all the people who make up WordCamp Asia – from attendees to speakers, sponsors to volunteers. Whether you’re a developer, blogger, or designer, the After Party is a melting pot of potential future collaborators (and friends!), so be sure to show up with your business card in hand and your creative ideas at the ready. 🙌🏻 

Experience the culture of Taipei

The After Party is an opportunity to experience more of Taipei – not just through experiencing new venues but also with local music and performances and regional delicacies. We know that spending three days inside a conference hall doesn’t always create connection to the outside world, which is why the After Party is your chance to soak up the culture of Taipei and all it has to offer. 

Celebrate the diversity of our community 

The After Party is also a chance for us to celebrate the unity and diversity of our community. In 2023, we invited attendees to celebrate their cultural heritage through their outfits – creating a fashion feast for the senses. We’ll be bringing a similar flavor to this years’ After Party, so don’t forget to pack something snazzy in your suitcase. 

The official After Party is a night not to be missed. We can’t wait to see you there.

Since many of us will be in Taipei for WordCamp Asia, companies and individuals may organize side events. This page serves to share those opportunities with all WordCamp Asia participants to encourage even more connection.

All side events listed here are not endorsed or organized by WordCamp Asia, nor do they conflict with the WordCamp Asia 2024 schedule. In addition, the organizer of a side event is strongly encouraged to have and follow a code of conduct (the Contributor Covenant is a great starting point!) and will be fully responsible for the side event.

If you would like to promote your products or services, please consider sponsoring WordCamp Asia instead.

Please note, attendees take full responsibility when organising or participating in Side Events.

Side Events will be listed once they pass through our review process. Kindly note that events that conflict with the WordCamp Asia 2024 schedule will NOT be listed.

This year’s mascot selection showcased the immense talent and creativity within our community. We received a total of 21 incredible submissions from 15 dedicated creators across the globe, including the USA, Italy, Malaysia, Taiwan, Nepal, India, Indonesia, and Japan. This diverse participation truly reflects the global spirit of WordPress and WordCamp.

The organizers voted for the Wapuu that can represent the vision that we have for WordCamp Asia 2024. We are now proud to announce WordCamp Asia 2024 mascot – Soup Dumpling Wapuu! 

Soup Dumpling Wapuu

Soup dumplings is one of the popular local foods in Taiwan.

We hope this lovely-designed Soup Dumpling Wapuu makes you hungry and want to try the tasty soup dumplings. 

Designer: Dian Shen Chen (Taiwan) 

Download Wapuu

Please feel free to utilize the Wapuu file for designing your own swag!

The Essence of Wapuu

Wapuu holds a special place in the WordPress community. Originally created for WordCamp Japan, Wapuu symbolizes the open-source spirit and the friendly, inclusive nature of WordPress. Over the years, Wapuu has evolved, taking on various forms and styles, each representing the unique facets of the WordPress community worldwide.

Last Update: February 28, 2024

Table of Contents
  1. Welcome
  2. Important Dates & Deadlines
  3. Schedule, Timing & Speaker Profiles
    1. Schedule
    2. Speaker Profile
    3. Emcee Schedule
    4. Speaker Survey
  4. A/V Details & Requirements
    1. Laptops used for presentation
    2. Technical Rehearsals
  5. TICC Room Layout
  6. Welcome Dinner
  7. After Party Details
  8. Registration
  9. Visa
  10. Venue & Hotel Accommodations
  11. Presentation Template & Slide Submission
    1. Templates
    2. Slide Submission
  12. Promote Your Session
  13. Code of Conduct
  14. Contact Us

Welcome

We are happy to welcome you as a speaker at WordCamp Asia 2024 🎉

The event will be in-person style at Taipei International Convention Center in Taipei, Taiwan from March 7th, Thursday – March 9th, Friday, 2024.

  • March 7th – Contributor Day *Separate Registration is needed
  • March 8th – Conference Day 1
  • March 9th – Conference Day 2

Please check the information shown on this page to help you guide until the day of the event.

Important Dates & Deadlines

  • Speakers Application Deadline: September 30, 2023
  • Speaker Outreach for Acceptance: Starting December 1
  • Acceptance, Agreement: Acceptance and Agreements are asked to be finished within 2023. Please check your email for the details.
  • Draft Slides Due: January 15th
  • Final Slide Check: February 15th
  • Event Day: March 8th & 9th.
    Please check the schedule page and email for when your session is scheduled.
    • Timezone: China Standard Time (UTC +8)
  • Final Slides Upload: Please share the final slides by February 15th by either the email or Slack.
  • Technical Rehearsal: March 7 3:00 pm (TICC Plenary Hall)
  • Welcome Dinner: March 7, 2024 7:00 pm (Super 346)
  • After Party March 9, 2024 7:00 pm (MAJI MAJI)

Schedule, Timing & Speaker Profiles

Schedule

Have a look at the schedule https://asia.wordcamp.org/2024/schedule/ to know the time and room of your talk.

Both day starts at 9:00AM and will have 60 min long break in noon. Most of the sessions will be 40 minutes long, with the exception of lightning talks – 10 minutes and workshops – 90 minutes long.

If you have a conflict with the timing of your talk, find that it conflicts with the content of another talk, or have any troubles, please contact the program team via asia-speakers@wordcamp.org.

Speaker Profile

Each speaker has their dedicated speaker page. The information shown in the page is from the application everyone has sent in. If anything has changed or would like to change your profile, please contact the Program Team via email or Slack.

  • Speakers: https://asia.wordcamp.org/2024/speakers/

Emcee Schedule

Since all the preparations are in the final stage and the schedule is now less likely to be changed unless we have some unforeseen circumstances so I would like to share the emcee schedules here. 

All the speakers please check your respective emcees.

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1y0qG1zPY9NV2jGPmNtffswXhrVtVkMTrT2xkXXWtqtQ/edit#gid=1467026270

Regarding the panel discussion, emcees will only introduce the moderator and further will be handled by moderator themselves

Speaker Survey

Please fill this survey with your information make it easier for the emcees to introduce you. 

Please take note of the pronunciation of your names, please put in how to do it phonetically so that everyone is introduced properly.

https://forms.gle/th7yPXGCFTfxBcsi8

A/V Details & Requirements

Laptops used for presentation

For your presentation, we will be using the laptop provided by our vendor. This is due to making sure that all slides show up on the screen and have speaker notes on the return monitor that each room has. So if you have a speaker note, please make sure they are added to your slides.

But if your slide contains certain fonts or you need to use your laptop for demo purposes, please let us know beforehand. In order to make this happen, we need to do the tech rehearsals with you on March 7th. /head

Technical Rehearsals

We are going to schedule a rehearsal in the afternoon (3pm to 5pm) on Contributor Day (March 7) for all speakers who want to test their presentations and presenter view on stage. 

This will be done in the Plenary Hall. 

Please reply to the message in the Slack Channel or send an email to asia-speakers@wordcamp.org to indicate if you want to join the rehearsal. 

Please note the following technical requirements:

  • All speakers will present from the computers we provide. If you wish to do a demo or any kind of solution that needs your own computer, please contact the program team about the details.
  • Presentation slides should be formatted in 16:9 aspect ratio. 
  • The room will include a screen, projector, and microphone; panelists will each receive their own microphones. The microphone for speakers is planned to be a headset type microphone.
  • If you require additional A/V equipments, please email asia-speakers@wordcamp.org with those needs by January 15th. The WordCamp Asia 2024 Organizing Team will make every effort to accommodate additional AV needs; however, final approval for additional A/V requests will be made on a case-by-case basis.

TICC Room Layout

Some of the speakers wanted to view the layout of the rooms in TICC. Please take a look at this URL to see the room layouts.

https://www.ticc.com.tw/wSite/sp?xdUrl=/wSite/ap/lp_VenueIntroduction_Eng.jsp&ctNode=388&CtUnit=155&BaseDSD=7&mp=2

WordCamp Asia team has also created a floor plans for Contributor Day and Main Conference Days:

  1. For Contributor Day: https://asia.wordcamp.org/2024/contributor-day-floor-plan/ 
  2. For Conference Day: https://asia.wordcamp.org/2024/ticc-floor-plan/ 

Welcome Dinner

We are looking forward to seeing you at the Welcome Dinner. During the Welcome Dinner, it would be great if our Program Team can say hi and maybe meet with our emcees and volunteers who will be helping you out for your session.

Venue:  Super 346

Time: 7 March 7:00pm~9:30pm

Location: https://maps.app.goo.gl/dzG7m1rBC8BB7hnj7

After Party Details

While we celebrate the fusion of technology and spring’s renewal, we are marking WordPress’s latest revitalization into its 21st year, a perfect reflection of Spring’s essence. This afterparty will highlight the beautiful interplay between digital innovation and natural rebirth. Embrace this season of new beginnings and technological advancements with us. 

⏰ Date & time: March 9, 2024 (Sat.) 19:00 ~ 24:00

📍 Location: MAJI MAJI (Address: No. 1, Yumen St, Zhongshan District, Taipei City, 10491 (MRT Station: Red Line Yuanshan Station)

🧚‍♀️ Dress code: Casual, family safe but we’d love for you to dress up for the theme!

Registration

Once you have accepted to talk at WordCamp Asia 2024, our team will send you a coupon code for you to use for the complimentary ticket. Please remember that this is only applicable to the speaker and cannot be transferred to others. The coupon code will be sent out via email. Please keep an eye on an email from asia-speakers@wordcamp.org.

If you already have a ticket and need to refund or transfer it, please refer to the dedicated pages.

  • Transfer Your Ticket: https://asia.wordcamp.org/2024/transfer-your-ticket/
  • Ticket Refund Process: https://asia.wordcamp.org/2024/ticket-refund-process/

Visa

WordCamp Asia 2024 Local Team will contact you via email to assist you with the visa application process. In the meantime, you can access visa-related information on our website: Visa Information Page.

Please note that we will provide all speakers with an invitation visa letter as part of the visa application support.

  • Important Visa Information: https://asia.wordcamp.org/2024/visa/

Venue & Hotel Accommodations

This year’s event will take place at: Taipei International Convention Center in Taipei, Taiwan. You can find more about the location in our dedicated page. https://asia.wordcamp.org/2024/location/

As of official hotel, we have partnered up with Grand Hyatt Taipei. If you consider staying at the official hotel, there is a special deal so please check your inbox for the emails we have sent you.

  • Official Hotel: https://asia.wordcamp.org/2024/official-hotel/

If you wish to stay at other hotels, we have listed out several recommendations.

  • Hotel Options: https://asia.wordcamp.org/2024/hotel-possibilities/

Presentation Template & Slide Submission

All speakers are required to submit their final presentation slides before the event for a final check by the team. We find that adding the presentations before the event helps to drive interest in attending the session. The final deadline for presentations is February 8th.

When creating your slides, these are some helpful informations you can reference:

  • Slide Decks – Make WordPress Community
  • Logos in Slide Decks and WordCamp Videos

Templates

We encourage all the speakers to explore their creative minds to create wonderful slides as you can, but we understand there are times when a template comes in handy. Our team is considering offering a template that everybody can use.

The information will be shared in the email and Slack Workspace in January.

Although we may provide a template, we do encourage and ask the speakers to explore with their slides.

Slide Submission

To submit your slides, you have these choices:

  1. Send an email to asia-speakers@wordcamp.org
  2. Contact the program team via the Slack Workspace

Promote Your Session

It would be lovely if you could promote your session. We are planning to create an individual opening slide image that one can use. The same image will be used in the session detail page also. We will inform the speakers once the image asset is ready.

Code of Conduct

Please read the Code of Conduct. It is strictly enforced and we ask the speakers to review them and follow them. We would also like to ask the speakers to be careful and to be inclusive in the words and images you use during your presentations.

Contact Us

If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to us via asia-speakers@wordcamp.org or the Slack Workspace.

content.rendered:
• Aaron D. Campbell

    Aaron is an international speaker, open source advocate, and outgoing introvert. He’s been a regular contributor to WordPress for more than a decade, and is currently Director of Product at A2 Hosting. His passion is helping companies work with the WordPress project to improve and support WordPress while providing better and more secure WordPress offerings to their customers.

  • Adam Silverstein

    Adam is a WordPress core committer where he works to fix bugs and improve modern web capabilities. Adam is a Developer Relations Engineer on Chrome’s Web Platform team at Google, where he focuses on making the open web better for everyone. Adam loves long rafting trips, playing mbira, travel, taking walks and tending his over-sized garden.

  • Alain Schlesser

    As the Principal Architect at Yoast, Alain specializes in navigating the complexities of scalability to enhance the company’s product offerings.

    His expertise is further recognized as a Google Developers Expert in Web Technologies, where he shares educational content with a focus on performance optimization and data privacy.

    In the WordPress community, Alain is known for serving as the maintainer of WP-CLI, the popular command-line interface that streamlines WordPress operations. His commitment also extends to the WordPress Core and adjacent projects, where he contributes his skills in various capacities.

    Beyond his technical contributions, Alain shares insights and experiences on coding and various topics through his website at https://www.alainschlesser.com. For a more casual exchange of ideas or to simply say hello, he welcomes connections on Twitter/X at @schlessera.

  • Alberto Medina

    Alberto Medina is a Developer Relations Engineering, currently working on the Privacy Sandbox Initiative at Google.

  • Alex Kirk

    Alex Kirk has been active in the WordPress universe as a developer since early days and has been leading teams in the area of internationalization and matrix at Automattic for 8 years. He is the author of the Friends plugin, which allows you to participate in Social Networks with your own WordPress.

  • Alfred, Cheng-Tai Kang

    I began my academic journey in the field of physics before pursuing my passion for digital arts, earning an MFA from Pratt Institute in 2005. After graduating, I worked in New York until 2011, immersing myself in the vibrant creative scene. My relationship with WordPress started in 2006, a platform that would later become instrumental in my career. Along with my team, we developed a wide array of customized WordPress programs, catering to various client needs. My work in digital arts was recognized with a Cannes Cyber Lion – Bronze and two FWA awards, accolades that fueled my drive for innovation.

    In 2011, I returned to Taiwan to embark on an entrepreneurial journey, founding a company that adopted WordPress as its primary development framework in 2015. This decision marked a significant turning point, aligning our technological approach with global standards.

    April 2023 brought a new fascination into my life when I was astounded by chatGPT, sparking an interest in AI research. This cutting-edge technology has since become a new frontier for my exploration.

    Beyond my professional life, I am the proud father of two young boys. Together, we embark on adventures, exploring the world and learning from each other. Our shared journey of learning to skateboard has become a cherished bonding experience, filled with laughter, challenges, and growth. Balancing my roles as an entrepreneur, innovator, and father, I continue to seek new horizons, driven by curiosity and a commitment to excellence.

  • Angela Jin

    Angela Jin is the Head of Programs and Contributor Experience at Automattic, where she oversees the work of four teams (community events and engagement, education, and marketing) dedicated to the WordPress open source project. Her passion lies in building strong, inclusive communities. In her spare time, Angela is a crisis counselor for Crisis Text Line. Originally from Washington, USA, Angela currently lives in Spain, where she delights in learning Spanish, exploring by eating, and reading a good book.

  • Anne-Mieke Bovelett

    Anne is a passionate multilingual accessibility and possibility advocate, currently living in Germany. She was born in 1971 in The Netherlands, into a family with a rich heritage of visual artists, sculptors, musicians, and eccentric professors. The source of her commercial genes is a mystery, but her passion for creating and designing has genetically been unavoidable. She built her first website in 1998 and freelanced on the side for many years. By 2008, Anne committed to full-time entrepreneurship.

    Anne relishes in playfully debunking myths like “accessible websites are more expensive” and “smashing designs can’t be achieved if the focus is on accessibility.” Her favourite terms in discussions with peers and clients are conversion, usability, and customer experience. She derives pleasure from raising awareness about profitable inclusive design and content, both within and beyond the WordPress community. The term ‘profitable’ in this context refers to both human and business aspects.

    What she cherishes most and does best is guiding companies to motivate all departments to ensure accessibility remains a priority throughout the organization. She deeply believes in providing access to the same opportunities and experiences for everyone, irrespective of any physical or mental limitations they may have.

  • Ben Thompson

    Ben has been publishing Stratechery on WordPress since 2013. Stratechery is a blog about technology and strategy, and the impact of the Internet on media. That includes blogging: Ben has, from the beginning, been a strong proponent of the idea that not only is blogging not dead but that its future is brighter than ever. That belief was undergirded by the possibility of new business models, particularly subscriptions. Ben proved that with Stratechery, one of the first subscription-supported blogs that created the model for the entire industry. Today Stratechery is a multi-million dollar content business, and Ben is an influential voice in Silicon Valley, Wall Street, and Washington D.C.

  • Benjamin Intal

    Benjamin has been building with WordPress since 2008. He specializes in developing page building tools for individuals & businesses. His passion for coding has paved the way for creating a variety of plugins that is used by over 150,000 websites globally.

    He is the founder of Gambit Technologies, and leads the team in developing Stackable – Website Builder for WordPress, one of the first & most widely used custom block collections for the WordPress Block Editor.

  • Bijay Yadav

    Bijay Yadav is an experienced WordPress developer specializing in creating captivating and functional websites since 2013. With a decade of expertise, he possesses a deep knowledge of WordPress’s core functionality, themes, and plugins. Bijay’s proficiency in front-end technologies, attention to detail, and strong communication skills enable him to deliver visually appealing and high-performing websites for clients across various industries. Committed to continuous learning, he stays updated with the latest trends to provide cutting-edge solutions. Bijay is dedicated to helping businesses establish their online presence and achieve their digital goals. He mostly works on eCommerce websites based on WooCommerce or Shopify. Whenever he has time, he also contributes to the WordPress community by reviewing WordPress themes.

    When you don’t find him working on WordPress, he is mostly busy playing with his toddler daughter, taking photographs, or traveling.

  • Chaya Oosterbroek

    Chaya Oosterbroek is the proud COO and former shareholder and board member of Yoast. She is a dedicated social entrepreneur, with a background of guiding companies and their entrepreneurs to the next level. It’s her passion to optimize business processes and reduce “waste”. She loves to engage people and drive them to the best performance within their capacities.

    Chaya is also a passionate advocate for authenticity and equality. Her mission is to empower individuals to embrace their true selves and create a world where everyone has equal opportunities. Chaya believes that true progress can only be achieved by embracing diversity and fostering an inclusive society.

    Not only does she celebrate Pride within the Yoast community, but she also extends her support outside of it. Things she has done include adjusting Yoasts’ HR guidelines so they are more inclusive, hosting Pride parties and sponsoring Pride interest groups.

  • Chiaki Kouno

    Chiaki Kouno is a Japanese digital marketer working with WordPress sites, sometimes a developer. Has been based in Hong Kong since 2008. Dim Sum lover. Marketing Representative of Vektor, Inc. in charge of domestic and international marketing. She was an organizer of WordCamp Hong Kong 2019 & Asia 2023. And as a speaker at WordCamp Tokyo 2019, Japan 2021, and Malaysia 2023. The designer of Tuk-tuk Wapuu & Chao Phraya Boat Wapuu of WordCamp Asia 2023.

  • Gerlynnia Aprille Galgo

    Gerlynnia Galgo is a brand strategist, content creator for designers, and digital marketer. She is the founder of GO Creatives, an independent creative studio that specializes in Branding, Brand Experiences, and Digital Marketing. Gerlynnia helps lifestyle and creative businesses implement strategies and thrive in the digital space. Her work and clients have been featured in prestigious publications such as Vogue, Smart Parenting Asia, Sunstar, and Forbes. In addition to her professional pursuits, she is a paper-cut and visual artist who also practices tattooing on the side.

  • Hannah KAO

    KAO, CHIH-HAN (高芷涵) is vice secretary general at Taiwan Gender Equity Education Association, responsible for infographic design, website management and fundraising. She never get tired of discovering the possibilities of using WordPress in nonprofit organizations.

  • Hannah Swain Løvik

    Hannah Swain Løvik is an open-source advocate focused on knowledge management, productivity, and people management – specifically supporting and empowering others. Originally a developer, she quickly moved on to information architecture, project management, teaching and training, supporting WordPress and building WordPress sites, and coaching.

    Hannah is currently a senior manager at Automattic, responsible for people management within WooCommerce and Happiness. She is based outside of Stockholm, Sweden.

  • Helen Tung

    Helen Tung is Founder of NewSpace2060, with a mission of empowering individuals and organisations to make better decisions.

    She is an international lawyer, speaker and consultant and trains entrepreneurs, advises organisations and businesses and speaks widely on topics including authenticity, alignment and working with the laws of nature and the Universe to optimise one’s strength and decision-making power. Helen is also an Adjunct lecturer on International Arbitration at the College of Law.

    She is the G100 Space Technology Chair (Australia), Vice – Chair of the Enterprise Risk Management Committee (ERMC) of the International Aeronautical Federation and Co-Chair of the IAA Symposium on Visions and Strategies (IP sessions).

    Helen is a member of the Dubai Courts of the Future Working Group; Associate Fellow of the Institute for Security and Development Policy; member of the International Institute of Space Law & European Centre for Space Law and board member of the International Institute of Space Law..

    She is interested in the intersection between law, space and medicine and currently a member of the IBA, IPBA, Australian Society of Stem Cell Research , Australasian Cell Death Society, World Association for Medical Law, Law and Medicine network JAMA.

    Inviting you to engage in idea sharing, collaboration and partnerships.

  • Hidetaka Okamoto

    Hide (ひで pronounced “Hee-Day”) is a Developer Advocate at Stripe, where he works on writing, coding, and teaching how to integrate online payments. He has organized several community conferences including WordCamp Kyoto and JP_Stripes Connect 2019, the first Stripe user conference in Japan. Prior to Stripe, Hide was a lead Software Engineer at DigitalCube, focused on building plugins, open source, and developing SaaS application dashboards. Hide lives in Hyogo, Japan with his family and two cats.

  • Jaclyn Chen

    Jaclyn grew up in Taichung, Taiwan, spent 9 years in the US for graduate school and work, then moved back to Taipei, Taiwan in 2018. She majored in electrical engineering in college, turned iOS developer after graduate school for 10 years, and has been focusing on the WooCommerce iOS app for the last 4 years. She is also a travel enthusiast and documented in a WordPress blog, and enjoys exploring outdoors and cultures.

  • Jeanne Tan

    Jeanne Tan is a seasoned digital marketing expert with over 10 years of experience, specializing in SEO strategy in the last 2 years. She has spearheaded successful campaigns across niches like test preparation, VPN, trailer manufacturing, and management coaching, establishing brands in global markets, including Australia, the UK, and North America.

    Currently, Jeanne drives SEO strategies for clients in the US and English-speaking regions of Europe, achieving remarkable growth in organic traffic — up to 250% in under a year. Her proficiency encompasses technical SEO, semantic search strategies, and SEO copyediting.

    Jeanne holds certifications from leading industry-recognized SEO and digital marketing institutions. She’s now laying the foundation for her own strategy-centric, SGE-ready SEO consultancy.

  • Jocelyn Hendrickson

    Jocelyn Hendrickson is a Senior Product Manager of WordPress Commerce at Bluehost with over 10 years of experience in the web hosting industry. She has a curious problem-solving mindset and a strong belief that there’s no limit to what can be built when you combine curiosity with creativity. Jocelyn has led numerous transformative projects, including successful third-party integrations, interface redesigns and system improvement projects that have transformed customer experiences. Her dedication to building products that revolutionize the way businesses succeed in the digital world is fueled by her passion for the intersection of technology, design, and user experience.

  • Joe A Simpson Jr

    WordPress has been a beautiful whirlwind for Joe Simpson since 2017. While on a 90-day leave of absence to recover from a heart event, he decided to truly give back, learn WordPress, and grow in areas he’s passionate about (like illustrating Wapuu).

    Joe didn’t see anyone onstage or organizing WordCamps that looked like him, so he presented at WordCamp Chicago while starting two Meetups, and created WordCamp Santa Clarita the first WordCamp north of Los Angeles and south of San Francisco since 2014.

    He co-founded BlackPress with Destiny Kano-Fox and Nyesha Sweet, most recently was one of the Lead Sextet that organized WordCamp US 2023 in National Harbor and is one of the Team Reps on Make WordPress Accessible.

  • Jonathan Desrosiers

    Jonathan has been using WordPress since 2007 to build sites of all sizes, from local businesses to enterprises and large universities. He has been a contributor to WordPress Core since 2013, and a WordPress Core committer since 2018. He passionately advocates for new contributors through mentorship and active leadership. Jonathan currently works as a Senior Software Engineer at Bluehost, where he is sponsored full-time to contribute to WordPress Core.

  • Joseph Jacks (JJ)

    Joseph Jacks is the Founder and General Partner of OSS Capital. He is based in San Francisco.

    Previously, Joseph was an EIR at Quantum Corporation in support of the Rook project which was subsequently donated to the CNCF (its first storage project) where he has also been involved (at the board level, in various committees and as an advisor) since inception. Joseph also founded KubeCon (now also run by the Linux Foundation’s CNCF) while also founding and building Kismatic, the first enterprise-focused commercial Kubernetes company (acquired by Apprenda, subsequently acquired by ATOS). Over the preceding several years, Joseph worked at Mesosphere (now D2IQ), Enstratius (acquired by Dell Software), TIBCO Software and Talend in various sales, engineering, product and strategy capacities.

    Joseph is also the founder of Open Core Summit, the global COSS ecosystem conference, run independently as a vendor0neutral community that includes the leading investment firms, cloud providers, COSS companies, analysts, F2000 enterprises and more. The first OCS occurred in San Francisco, September 19-20th, 2019, uniting nearly 1,000 attendees across 29 countries, 40 major sponsors and 100~ speakers. The second annual OCS 2020 occurred fully online from December 16-18th, 2020, with 13,000+ attendees, 200~ speakers and 50~ major sponsors, celebrating and democratizing knowledge about the meteoric growth of the COSS category.

  • Josepha Haden Chomphosy

    Josepha Haden Chomphosy currently serves as the Executive Director of the WordPress project, one of the most widely used content management systems in the world. With a background in communications and digital media, she brings a unique perspective to the world of technology. She is passionate about creating inclusive communities and helping people develop the skills they need to succeed in the digital age.

    Since joining WordPress in 2019, Josepha has focused on building a more diverse and inclusive community, expanding the reach of the platform, and empowering users to create amazing digital experiences.

    She is known for her leadership skills, her passion for open source software, and her commitment to creating a more equitable and inclusive tech industry. She is a sought-after speaker and mentor, and has been recognized for her contributions to the world of technology and beyond.

    You can read her occasional writing on josepha.blog

  • JU-CHUN KO

    Dr. JU-CHUN (JC) KO, currently an At-Large Legislator and adjunct assistant professor at the Graduate Institute of Networking and Multimedia at National Taiwan University, has been deeply engaged with the CMS community in Taipei since 2004 and actively involved in blog writing. After earning his Ph.D. in Computer Science from National Taiwan University in 2012, he proceeded to Keio University’s Graduate School of Media Design (KMD) in Japan for postdoctoral research and later attended Singularity University in the US. 

    He also served as the Taiwan AI/Web3 Growth Partner for the Dentsu Group in Japan. Besides founding the well-known technology podcast “dAb in Tech,” he has actively organized and participated in WordPress-related gatherings and lectures, including the Taipei WordPress Meetup in 2013 and a smaller gathering in 2017. 
    This year, he is honored to have been invited to speak at WordCamp Asia 2024. His digital journey spans from early blog writing to exploring the cutting edge of Web3 and decentralized publishing, especially in promoting and applying the “Writing as NFT” system developed by the LikeCoin organization in Hong Kong on the WordPress platform. His expertise lies in merging legislative insights with digital innovation, building a bridge between traditional web technologies and the emerging Web3 ecosystem, committed to driving progress in technology and society.

  • Kimberley Cole

    As a long-term resident of Hong Kong, Kimberley has worked and led teams across the region.  Whilst at Thomson Reuters her team of 160 sales professionals generated $US90 Million in revenue for the 1.1 Billion dollar business in the region. She joined Yoast in May 2023 when appointed as General Manager, Europe for Newfold Digital.She is an award-winning, Global Senior Executive with 25+ years of Sales & Marketing Leadership experience and believes in constant innovation and inspiring purpose to generate business & attract & develop high-performing teams.Kimberley is the founder of innovative industry networks ‘Women in Finance Asia’ & the global ‘Risky Women network for professional women in Risk, Regulation, and Compliance. She is also the Chief Risky Woman and the host of the podcast series, ‘Risky Women Radio’.

  • Kimberly Pater

    By day, Kimberly Pater is a Technical Account manager for WP Engine. By night, she runs her own small creative agency, Bumbershoot Creative, where she tackles various technical and creative projects including website design and development, performance optimisations, and video production. She is passionate about best practice development, keeping the internet open and accessible, and open-source technologies. A lover of classic sci-fi, her two furry technical assistants are named Isaac and Asimov.

  • Lorna Lim

    As an Account Manager in the APAC region, Lorna looks after Human Made’s client accounts to ensure successful and sustainable delivery of value for Human Made’s clients, and to ensure that the delivery teams have a well structured and rewarding set of client needs to meet.

    Prior to joining Human Made, Lorna was a Business Innovation Consultant, combining trend research, design thinking and business strategy to help companies develop innovative products, services and experiences. She graduated from Singapore Management University with double majors in Marketing and Finance.

    Lorna is born and based in Singapore. On evenings and weekends, you will likely find her Salsa dancing.

  • Luke Carbis

    Luke Carbis is a self-deputised open-source emissary and vigilante plenipotentiary for WordPress proletariat affairs. He works closely with WordPress product companies to fast-track their growth and inspire beautifully written code. He’s been part of the community as a plugin developer, core contributor, release lead, WordCamp organiser, and a member of the plugin review team.

  • Maestro Stevens

    Maestro Stevens is a highly skilled brand webmaster and founder of The Iconic Expressions creative agency. He has 8+ years of experience in marketing strategy, brand strategy, website development, and project management. He enjoys using technology and strategies to simplify life, cooking, reading, and traveling. Recently Maestro has developed a platform under his agency called Iconic Templates, which focuses on creating free and premium templates for WordPress users.

  • Matt Mullenweg

    Matt Mullenweg is co-founder of the open-source publishing platform WordPress, which now powers over one-third of all sites on the web. He is the founder and CEO of Automattic, the company behind WordPress.com, WooCommerce, Tumblr, WPVIP, Day One, and Pocket Casts. Additionally, Matt runs Audrey Capital, an investment and research company. He has been recognized for his leadership by Forbes, Bloomberg Businessweek, Inc. Magazine, TechCrunch, Fortune, Fast Company, Wired, University Philosophical Society, and Vanity Fair.

    Matt is originally from Houston, Texas, where he attended the High School for the Performing and Visual Arts and studied jazz saxophone. In his spare time, Matt is an avid photographer. He currently splits his time between Houston and Jackson.

  • Michelle Frechette

    Michelle Frechette is the Director of Community Engagement for StellarWP at Liquid Web.

    Michelle was called “The busiest woman in WordPress,” by Matt Mullenweg at WCUS 2022.

    In addition to her work at StellarWP, Michelle is the Podcast Barista at WPCoffeeTalk.com, cofounder of underrepresentedintech.com, creator of WPSpeakers.com, creator of wpcareerpages.com, the president of the board for BigOrangeHeart.org, Director of Community Relations and contributor at PostStatus.com, co-host of the WPMotivate podcast, co-host of the Audacity Marketing podcast, cohost of the WP Constellations podcast, author, and a frequent organizer and speaker at WordPress events. Michelle lives outside of Rochester, NY where she’s an avid nature photographer.

    You can learn more about Michelle at meetmichelle.online.

  • Milana Cap

    When was the last time you tested code in production? Your own website doesn’t count.

    Conversations with the Terminal, or WP-CLI for PHP developers, is the sequel of WordPress through the Terminal talk, focusing on a set of commands and tools useful for PHP developers.

    This is not just a live demo of WP-CLI commands. This is zooming out and seeing WP-CLI in collaboration with other tools in the context of PHP developer needs and everyday tasks. We’ll probably release the Kraken as well.

  • Mina Tamang

    Mina is an SEO Analyst with over 6 years of experience in the digital marketing industry. Her passion for SEO helped her specialize in on-page and technical SEO. In addition, her curious and passionate nature honed her skill in content marketing as well.

    Mina started her journey with WordPress in 2020 and is now an SEO Analyst at Codewing Solutions. She is excited to be a part of the WordPress community and help others learn about the power of WordPress.

    When she is not optimizing websites and improving their search visibility, you can find her indulging in her love for music. Listening to different genres and discovering new artists brings her joy and helps her unwind after a productive day.

  • MinUk Kim

    I am a member of the TeamH4C hacking team, and I am researching the field of web hacking. We have also developed a black box-based web vulnerability scanner.

    I belong to the TeamH4C hacking team, and I am researching the field of web hacking and have worked on a black box-based web vulnerability scanner as a project. also reported a simple WordPress Plugin vulnerability.

  • Miriam Schwab

    Miriam co-founded and built Strattic to bring an innovative and comprehensive approach to WordPress security and performance to the web at large. After being acquired by Elementor, Miriam continued to lead the Strattic unit until taking on the role of Head of WordPress Relations at Elementor to act as a liaison between Elementor and the greater WordPress ecosystem.

    Prior to founding Strattic, Miriam founded and managed one of Israel’s leading WordPress development agencies, which was also subsequently acquired. In both of the companies she founded, Miriam and her team worked with top executives and enterprise organizations to help them build and deploy effective web presences.

    With over fifteen years of experience in the web and WordPress industry, Miriam is an active member of the WordPress community and WordCamp organizer, as well as a recognized expert and global speaker.

  • Nada ElSharkawy

    Nada joined GoDaddy in 2021 as the Marketing Manager for Middle East and North Africa, she’s currently Senior Manager, Marketing and part of the commercial Strategy team. Nada enjoys long walks in parks and visiting local coffee shops to satisfy her taste buds. She is the sole recommender of good restaurants to her friends and never disappoints them.

  • Naoko Takano

    Naoko has been a part of the organizing teams of WordCamps, Meetups, and do_action events in Tokyo and Japan. She currently contributes to the WordPress project as a project manager for contributor growth projects including Five for the Future and mentorship program.

  • Nirav Mehta

    Nirav is an unusual combination of a geek + entrepreneur + storyteller + mentor. If you have any questions about WordPress, WooCommerce; running or scaling a tech business, he’s your goto guy!

    Over the last twenty five years he’s launched India’s first electronic magazine, a 120 people web agency, lots of open source contributions and a string of successful product businesses. He has authored three books.

    He currently leads StoreApps.org, Icegram.com, Putler.com and Offermative.com

    Be sure to ask him about his longevity hacks when you meet him next…

  • Noel Tock

    Noel has been building digital experiences since 1995, and has helped build Human Made, one of the leading WordPress companies. There, he works with a range of enterprise clients to advise them on growing large platforms, by fusing open-source and innovative technologies for lasting value. He’s now using this experience to also volunteer in the recovery of Ukraine, hoping to make a difference through humanitarian technology.

  • Olga Gleckler

    Olga is a developer with over 15 years of experience in software support, marketing and web development. She is an active WordPress contributor, Codeable expert and fantasy writer.

    Olga has been contributing to WordPress since 2019 and is currently WordPress 6.5 release Test co-lead and actively participate in the Contributor Mentorship Program. She believes in open-source and is passionate about everything she does. She likes rock music and sharing knowledge.

  • Paolo Belcastro

    Paolo is a modern nomad: after Italy, France, and Switzerland, he currently lives in Vienna, Austria, where he works on Automattic’s Jetpack and .blog products.

    A passionate photographer, he publishes his photos on paolo.blog and shares his thoughts on Morfternight, a weekly newsletter about Leadership, Ai, and Photography.

    Working remotely since 1994 and managing distributed teams since 1998, he firmly believes that remote work is the key to peaceful coexistence for 10 billion humans.

  • Pascal Birchler

    Pascal Birchler is a long-standing WordPress community member and core committer. As part of the core performance team he is currently working on accelerating the web through CMSes like WordPress. Living in a multilingual country, he is passionate about internationalization and improving this area in WordPress to make software accessible for everyone.

  • Perth Woratana Ngarmtrakulchol

    Perth is currently working as analytics engineer at Canva. He has been working and contributing to WordPress community for more than 10 years. He co-founded WordPress community in Thailand with his friends, and you might have seen him running around in the community events such as WordCamp Bangkok and WordCamp Asia 2023.

  • Petya Raykovska

    Petya is the Director of Agency Operations at Human Made, a global distributed WordPress agency that has been servicing enterprise clients for more than a decade.

    In her many years in the software development industry, she’s also held roles in marketing and event management, business operations, project and community management.

    Petya’s been an active member of the WordPress community since 2011 – volunteering and organising events and supporting the global WordPress Polyglots team as a translation editor and global translation community mentor.

  • Phoomparin Mano

    A software engineer from Bangkok, Thailand who advocates for open-source, modern web development, type-safe frontends, and building communities for developers to be more creative and learn in public.

    Codes in TypeScript and Rust. Co-founder of Creatorsgarten, a collective of nerds and creative technologists in Thailand. Former VP of Engineering at Brikl. Lover of cute plushies, onsen baths, Japanese food, medium-rare steaks and macarons.

  • Rahul Bansal

    Rahul is the founder & CEO of rtCamp — a WordPress consultancy agency serving household brands across the world. Rahul started using WordPress as a professional blogger in 2007. In his 17 years journey, he has contributed to the WordPress community in different ways, including theme and plugins development, as a WordCamp speaker and organizer, and through side projects such as EasyEngine.

  • Rich Tabor

    As a multidisciplinary maker specializing in the intersection of product, design and engineering, Rich Tabor is recognized as one of the top leaders in this era of WordPress. His precise design chops have topped the Automattic Design Awards and led him to create multiple products that have attained millions of users.

    Rich is currently a Product Manager at Automattic, working directly on WordPress, focusing on making publishing more intuitive and human-centric all around.

  • Ricky Blacker

    Ricky is a self taught web professional who found and fell in love with WordPress, and the community behind it while looking for a CMS platform to build websites for clients.

    He originally started his own web design business after being made redundant from a factory job in 2013, but now works for WP Engine as a Partner Enablement Manager and WordPress Evangelist.

    He is a Co-Organizer for the Brisbane and Sunshine Coast WordPress Meetup Groups, and has spoken at WordCamps in Australia, New Zealand and Singapore.

  • Robert Li

    Recovering Startup Founder, Lifelong Technologist, Doctor of Media and Games Studies, WordPress Evangelist, Tinkerer, and APAC Automator in Chief & currently Principal Solutions Engineer for WP Engine.

  • Ryan Welcher

    Ryan is a Developer Advocate sponsored by Automattic. He focuses on removing barriers to adoption for developers working with Gutenberg and WordPress. He is a seasoned WordPress developer and regular contributor to WordPress and the Gutenberg project. He also streams on Twitch as RyanWelcherCodes were he focuses on custom block development.

  • SHEN YI TING

    I have over three years of experience in the cybersecurity industry, focusing primarily on researching network security-related technologies. I frequently participate in various events as a speaker and also organize activities.

    Outside of work, I dedicate my time to different research projects and actively discover security vulnerabilities across various platforms.

  • Siobhan McKeown

    Siobhan is COO of Human Made, a global enterprise WordPress agency and the makers of Altis DXP. She is one of the founders of WordCamp Europe, and a long-term contributor to the WordPress project, where she once led the docs team and wrote a book about the history of the project. She is a remote work advocate and her book, A Life Lived Remotely: Being and Work in the Digital Age, was published in 2019.

  • Tammie Lister

    Tammie Lister is a product creator focusing on WordPress. She has a hybrid background across product, design, psychology and development. She contributes to WordPress and is passionate about Open Source, community and drinking tea.

  • Tim Ferriss

    Update [ March 4, 2024, 12pm (UTC+8) ]

    Tim Ferriss is unable to speak at WordCamp Asia due to unforeseen circumstances. 

    Tim Ferriss has been listed as one of Fast Company’s “Most Innovative Business People” and one of Fortune’s “40 under 40.” He is an early-stage technology investor/advisor (Uber, Facebook, Shopify, Duolingo, Alibaba, and 50+ others) and the author of five #1 New York Times and Wall Street Journal bestsellers, including The 4-Hour Workweek and Tools of Titans: The Tactics, Routines, and Habits of Billionaires, Icons, and World-Class Performers. The Observer and other media have called Tim “the Oprah of audio” due to the influence of The Tim Ferriss Show podcast, which is the first business/interview podcast to exceed 100 million downloads. It has now exceeded 900 million downloads.

  • Wes Theron

    I am an Instructional Designer and strong supporter of the open-source movement. I have a background in education and content development. I am part of the WordPress Training Team and have been creating content for Learn.wordpress.org for the last two years. I am a husband, father, dreamer and lifelong learner.
