Refunds are only possible before 6 February 2024.

If you have purchased a WordCamp Asia 2024 ticket but are unable to attend the event, we encourage you to either cancel your ticket or request a refund. This helps make tickets available to others on the waiting list and allows them to attend WordCamp Asia 2024. Cancelling your ticket and requesting a refund is an easy way to support your fellow members of the WordPress community.

How to Refund Your Ticket

To refund your ticket, there are four steps:

  1. Check your inbox
  2. Click on the link in the email
  3. Request a Refund
  4. Confirm and Complete

Step 1: Check your inbox

First, search your email inbox for the subject line ‘Your Ticket to WordCamp Asia 2024’ to find your ticket confirmation email. If you can’t locate your ticket confirmation email, please contact us, and we’ll resend it to you.

Step 2: Click on the link in the email

To get a refund for your purchased ticket, visit the ticket edit access link in your WordCamp Asia 2024 ticket confirmation email.

Step 3: Request a Refund

Click the “request a refund” link on your ticket page.

Step 4: Confirm and Complete

After clicking on the request refund link, you will be taken to the refund request form. While it is optional to include a reason for the refund, you must check the “I agree to the above terms” checkbox and click the “Send Request” button to complete the process.

Cancellation Form

If you’re unable to request a refund, please contact us, and we will process it manually for you.

Please note that it may take a few days for your refund to be processed. When requesting a refund, please be aware that all tickets purchased together will be canceled. We are unable to provide partial refunds or transfer refunds to a different account. Kindly agree to these terms if you wish to proceed with the refund.

If you choose to cancel your ticket, it will no longer be transferable or redeemable as it will be added to the pool of available tickets that can be repurchased by others. Please carefully consider whether or not you will be able to attend the event before making any changes to your ticket, as transfers and cancellations may not be possible after the fact.

If you have been selected as a speaker, volunteer, or AV Crew and have already redeemed your ticket for a specific purpose, please note that these tickets can only be cancelled. If you have any questions or need assistance with your ticket, please feel free to send us an email, and we’ll be happy to assist you.

WordPress powers over 43% of the web, and WordCamp Asia is the flagship gathering of developers, designers and business owners who are using it to shape the online landscape in the region. 

If you’re a publication with a focus on tech, online trends and digital products, becoming a Media Partner provides you and your team with exclusive access to WordCamp Asia speakers, partners, and audiences. It’s an opportunity to connect with the people who are shaping the future of the internet in Asia, and get the inside scoop on the latest features, products and services being developed. 

We’re currently accepting applications from magazines, newspapers, TV and radio stations, podcasters, bloggers, influencers, and freelance journalists with an interest in WordPress and the future of the web. Apply now to become part of the WordCamp Asia community. 

Apply now

Why become a Media Partner

As a Media Partner of WordCamp Asia, you will: 

  • Get behind-the-scenes access to WordCamp Asia, the region’s flagship WordCamp event attracting thousands of attendees from around the globe.
  • Secure access to a network of speakers including entrepreneurs, business and agency owners, publishers, and digital storytellers helping to shape the future of the internet. 
  • Connect with a network of WordCamp Partners, which in 2023 included Google, Cloudways, Jetpack, GoDaddy Pro and Yoast. 
  • Have dedicated access to the Media Studio Room for your interviews, podcasts and streams.
  • Promote your brand to audiences from across Asia and the globe. 

What you’ll receive

Media Partners receive:

  • Recognition as an official Media Partner, including your logo and website link on the WordCamp Asia 2024 website
  • Promotion across WordCamp Asia’s social media channels
  • Media Passes to the event
  • Access to speakers for live interviews (subject to availability)
  • Exclusive access to graphics and media
  • Free meals and refreshments during the conference
  • Admission to social events

Media Partners are committed to:

We want to work with you to craft the content that feels most compelling to your audiences. When you apply to become a Media Partner, we’ll work with you to find the best fit. 

Depending on the medium you use, we ask you to share the best of WordCamp Asia on your channel—starting from the moment you join until a week after the event has ended.

content.rendered:
Call for Volunteer is closed.

WordCamp Asia 2024 is fast approaching, and we would need passionate volunteers for it. Our Volunteers were vital in the WordCamp Asia, 2023 in Bangkok. Volunteers are crucial for any event to be a success, hence we are looking for one in various roles. Join us, if you are self-motivated, respectful and committed towards making the grand event a success.

Participating in this event and becoming an active member of the WordPress Community presents an excellent opportunity in your WordPress career. As a volunteer, your role may involve various responsibilities, including assisting speakers, managing the help desk, offering support to participants, overseeing the coordination of tools and equipment, arranging microphones, and handling other technical aspects.

We appreciate and acknowledge the distinct talents possessed by each individual. In light of your unique abilities and interests, our organizing team is highly adaptable in assigning you suitable responsibilities. You have the opportunity to volunteer in various capacities such as blogging, photography, design, or even website administration. We truly value any assistance you can offer, and we are open to utilizing your skills. As long as you possess the willingness to contribute to making WordCamp a truly enjoyable and unforgettable experience for all, including yourself, we consider that to be sufficient.

When considering prospective volunteers, it’s vital to have accountability and trust in each other.  Accountability ensures you take responsibility for your commitments, professionalism, and punctuality. Effective communication and kindness are important to us. Trust creates an environment of reliance on capabilities, intentions, and ethical conduct. These principles enable collaborative, impactful volunteering for lasting positive change in communities.

Why Volunteer?

WordCamp Asia exhibits as a remarkable occasion and the largest WordCamp in Asia, attracting individuals from around the globe. The opportunity to engage with such a diverse community alone serves as an enticing reason. Furthermore:

  • Embrace the finest platform to join the continuously expanding WordPress community. Let’s acknowledge the fact that WordPress surpasses being a mere content management system, and it holds equal importance to explore its various dimensions.
  • This WordCamp takes place in the captivating and vibrant city of Taipei, Taiwan, offering a splendid chance to both explore a beautiful tourist destination and establish valuable connections.
  • Participants, volunteers, speakers, and sponsors hail from various corners of the world. This event serves as an excellent platform for networking, fostering friendships, and nurturing professional relationships.
  • Gain valuable insights into the organization and successful execution of such global events.
  • Adding this event to your CV showcases your contribution to the community, serving as a testament to your dedication.

Additionally, as a volunteer, you will receive a volunteer T-shirt, delightful goodies, and recognition. We warmly welcome individuals who are eager to dedicate their time to supporting the community. If you possess a friendly, helpful, and responsible nature, you are an ideal fit to join us. If you are worrying about your background being no match then no to worry, as every volunteer possesses unique talents, and you can contribute based on your skills and interests. Whether you’re interested in greeting people at the registration desk, emceeing a panel to introduce our speakers, or welcoming newcomers at the community table, there are various areas where your assistance will be valued. Rest assured, there is a volunteer role that can benefit from your aid!

If this event fills you with excitement, if Taiwan is a destination you yearn to visit, and if you are ready for an experience that not only enhances your CV but also creates unforgettable memories, hesitate no further. Come aboard and complete the application below. We will finalize the list of volunteers by 1st November 2023.

Wishing you all the best. We are already thrilled to welcome you into the WordCamp Asia family. Cheers!

Should you buy a ticket?

You can purchase a ticket when ticket sales have opened. If you are selected as a volunteer, we will be giving you a complimentary ticket to attend the event. Then you can transfer your purchased ticket to someone else. 

Please note: If you have purchased a ticket and are selected as a volunteer, the tickets will be refunded. So, don’t have to wait for volunteer vetting process.

Visa Letter

If you require a visa to travel to Taiwan in 2024, let us know in your application so that we can send you a letter to make your visa application process smoother. This is not a letter of invitation, but it will state the following:

  • That you are attending the event
  • The dates of the conference
  • The purpose of the conference

For further visa information, we will prepare another post to list the application rules in Taiwan. Please stay tuned.

Apply Now

content.rendered:
We are excited to have participants from various corners of the globe at WordCamp Asia 2024! Depending on your nationality, you may have different visa requirements to enter Taiwan. 

Note: We are providing this information as is and we are not the official authority on such matters. Please continue to consult your country’s immigration offices and relevant embassies.

Here’s what you need to know: 

  1. Before traveling to Taiwan, ensure that your passport remains valid for at least six months.
  2. Check which visa you need:

If you are not eligible for: Visa-Exempt Entry, or ROC Travel Authorization Certificate, you can apply for Visitor Visa for Attending Conference or Special MOFA’s eVisa through WordCamp Asia. You can determine the visa you need by country on meettaiwan.com.

The submission for the special MOFA’s eVisa through WordCamp Asia is closed as of 2024/2/14.

There’s also a Taiwan Gold Card in the Digital Fields program available to everyone, which allows for multiple entries and travel incentives to Taiwan. Please note that applying for both a visa and a Gold Card simultaneously does not present any conflicts.

(1) Visa-Exempt Entry and (2) ROC Travel Authorization Certificate  

(1) Visa-Exempt Entry

Taiwan has visa-exemption agreements with 65 countries, allowing their citizens to enter Taiwan for short stays without a visa. If your country is on the visa-exemption list, you can travel to Taiwan without obtaining a visa beforehand, but please verify the maximum stay period applicable to your nationality.

Stay of up to 90 days:  Andorra, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Canada, Chile, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Eswatini*, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Guatemala, Haiti, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan*, Republic of Korea, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Marshall Island*, Monaco, Netherlands, New Zealand, North Macedonia*(effective till March 31, 2025), Norway, Palau, Paraguay, Poland, Portugal, Romania, San Marino, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Tuvalu*, the United Kingdom, the United States of America*, and Vatican City State. 

Stay of up to 30 days: Belize*, Malaysia, Nauru, St. Kitts and Nevis*, Saint Lucia*, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, and Singapore. 

Stay of up to 14 days: Thailand, Philippines

For detailed information, please visit meettaiwan.com. 

Before arriving in Taiwan, please complete an online immigration arrival card on the website of the National Immigration Agency.

(2) ROC Travel Authorization Certificate

Nationals of Cambodia, India, Indonesia, Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam are eligible for online application for ROC Travel Authorization Certificate.

For detailed information, please go to meettaiwan.com. 

Note: When applying for ROC TAC, you could fill in your hotel as your Taiwan contact.

(3) Visitor Visa for Attending Conference and (4) MOFA’s eVisa Program Flexible Mechanism

The conference visa is designed to simplify travel arrangements for events like WordCamp Asia 2024, ensuring a seamless experience in Taipei. Whether you’re self-applying or exploring MOFA’s eVisa Program, this specialized visa provides the necessary authorization for conference participation.

If you are not eligible for: 

(1) Visa-Exempt Entry, or

(2) ROC Travel Authorization Certificate 

You will need to apply for (regardless of which country you come from):

(3) Visitor Visa for Attending Conference, or

(4) MOFA’s eVisa with the flexible mechanism through WordCamp Asia

(3) Visitor Visa for Attending Conference

This visa is specifically designed for conference attendees and provides you with the necessary authorization to participate in the event. Please note that an interview may be required, and you may need to visit the nearest Taiwanese embassy or consulate.

As part of the application process, you will need to provide evidence of documents, which includes an invitation letter. Please print out the visa invitation letter and proof of conference ticket (email subject: Your Ticket to WordCamp Asia 2024) to complete your visa application.

For detailed information, please go to boca.gov.tw. 

(4) MOFA’s eVisa Program Flexible Mechanism

The submission for the special MOFA’s eVisa through WordCamp Asia is closed as of 2024/2/14.

Traveling to Taiwan may pose challenges for attendees from specific countries. Therefore, we are committed to providing you with a seamless online eVisa application experience. Through collaboration with government organizations, we have streamlined the application process and outlined the timeline, aiming to alleviate your concerns and prepare you for your visit to Taiwan. 

  1. The eVisa is a single-entry visa, allowing a maximum stay in Taiwan of 30 days.
  2. Please note that you do NOT need to visit an embassy to obtain an eVisa. 
  3. According to the eVisa flexible mechanism policy, we can only submit your eVisa application one month before the event, which will be after February 7.
  4. eVisa application will be closed on 2024/02/03 (extended deadline 2024/02/14). The application link can be found in your ticket confirmation email.

Special eVisa Requirements

  • A valid passport with a remaining validity of at least six months
  • A clear digital copy of your passport’s bio page
  • Proof of your return flight ticket and accommodation plan
  • A ticket for the WordCamp Asia 2024 event
  • The eVisa application form provided by WordCamp Asia via ticket confirmation email
  • Visa fees vary by country. (english version starting at page 5) 

Special eVisa Application Process 

Step 1: Purchase your WordCamp Asia 2024 event ticket.
*Ensure that the registration details match the first and last name on your passport. 

Step 2: Book your round-trip flight and accommodation. 

Step 3: Fill out the eVisa application form that you’d receive via email from WordCamp Asia 
*This application will be reviewed by WordCamp Asia and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA)

Step 4: Receive an Ecode and an official English invitation letter via email
* The Open Culture Foundation (OCF) serves as the local representative entity for WordCamp Asia 2024 in Taiwan. They provide assistance with the eVisa process and support our event’s finance operations in the region.

Step 5: Use the Ecode to apply for eVisa and pay visa fee ONLINE after Feb 10, 2024

Step 6: Receive the eVisa result via email 

Step 7: Print out the eVisa result and the official invitation letter

Step 8: Present the printed documents before boarding and at immigration 

Welcome to Taiwan! 

For Attendees Requiring a Letter of Invitation

Please note that the visa invitation letter is only valid with a WordCamp Asia event ticket. Please print out your ticket confirmation email or the ticket editing page and attach it to your visa invitation letter (Ticket Confirmation Email Subject: Your Ticket to WordCamp Asia 2024). Additionally, please ensure that the name appearing on the ticket confirmation matches your passport name to avoid any discrepancies during your visa application process.

Read the instructions above and request your visa invitation letter here.

Still got Visa Questions? We’re Here to Help!

We are committed in our support for all attendees to participate in WordCamp Asia 2024 smoothly and without unnecessary obstacles. If you have any questions or concerns regarding visa requirements or the Letter of Invitation process, please don’t hesitate to contact our local team at asia-local@wordcamp.org.

We eagerly anticipate your presence at WordCamp Asia 2024, where we will come together to celebrate open source and the community!

content.rendered:
Why sponsor WordCamp Asia 2024?

The WordCamp Asia 2024 Call for Sponsors is now closed.

During the world’s first WordCamp Asia in 2023 we saw a phenomenal turnout of 1299 attendees, a number rivaling that of other flagship WordCamps. Sponsors and attendees alike voiced wide appreciation for the event, with sponsors sharing that the setup experience and booth received was top tier, and attendees from all over the world sharing love for the event. Some attendees even proclaimed that WordCamp Asia 2023 was the best WordCamp they’d ever been to!

We’d be delighted to have you be a part of making WordCamp Asia 2024 an even bigger celebration of WordPress and its tremendous community.

Taiwan is an island filled with an abundance of beauty, and when you visit you’ll understand why when the Portuguese saw Taiwan in 1542, they noted it on their maps as Ilha Formosa, meaning “beautiful island”. In honor of Taiwan’s natural landscapes, we offer you packages named after five of its many majestic mountain ranges.

content.rendered:
Call for Speakers is closed.

WordCamp Asia 2024 is the biggest WordPress event in Asia. We are looking for speakers to share their knowledge and expertise on a variety of topics related to WordPress and beyond.

  1. Are you ready to share your knowledge and expertise at the largest WordPress event in Asia?
  2. What topics are you interested in speaking about?
  3. How long should your presentation be?
  4. Which language should your talk be in?
  5. Do you have to be an experienced speaker to apply?
  6. Do you need help with your talk?
  7. Underrepresented Speaker Support
  8. When is the application deadline?
    1. What are the next steps?
    2. How many talks can you submit?
    3. Should you buy a ticket?
    4. Are you open to be a backup speaker?
    5. Visa Letter

Are you ready to share your knowledge and expertise at the largest WordPress event in Asia?

We are excited to announce that the Call for Speakers for WordCamp Asia 2024 is now open! We trust that we will receive many interesting applications for WordCamp Asia 2024 and are looking forward to reading all your proposals for our second WordCamp Asia.

This call is not only for those seeking to speak at WordCamp Asia 2024, but also host or join panel discussion or host a workshop for those attending the event.

What topics are you interested in speaking about?

We accept ALL topics related to WordPress and more. We are especially interested in hearing about diverse topics and inspirational stories. Topics such as trends, new approaches, and upcoming changes in related software and WordPress itself will be encouraged. Here are some of the topic examples:

  • Accessibility
  • Agile frameworks
  • AI (Artificial Intelligence) with WordPress
  • Business and Entrepreneurship
  • Career in WordPress
  • Case Studies and Success Stories
  • Community and Culture
  • Content Creation
  • Contribution Stories
  • Development
  • Design and User Experience
  • Diversity, Equity, and Inclusivity
  • FSE (Site Editor)
  • Headless WP
  • Marketing and SEO
  • Security
  • Storytelling
  • Success stories
  • Web3 and Open Web
  • What is next in WordPress?
  • WordPress 6.4
  • Working remotely best practices

How long should your presentation be?

We are planning the following formats for sessions:

Long Talk

40 minutes total (30 minutes for talk + 10 minutes for Q&A)

Lightning Talks

10 minutes total (10 minutes for talk only. No Q&A)

Panel Discussions

Around 60 minutes with Q&A

Workshops

90 minutes up to half a day

Which language should your talk be in?

All talks must be in English.

We understand that English may not be your first language. If you have any difficulties giving a talk in English, please let us know and we may assist you with your talks or guide you to any of the members within the WordPress community who are willing to help out.

Do you have to be an experienced speaker to apply?

No, you do not have to be an expert speaker to apply. However, we do recommend that you have some speaking experience. Speaking in front of a broad audience can be overwhelming even for experienced speakers, which is why we want to lend a helping hand. The Program team will be sharing resources and tips on how to put together a successful presentation as well as how to be more comfortable on stage. The Program team can organize a diversity speaker session or help get a mentor for you.

When reviewing applications, we will take into account your previous speaking experience, you can share videos of you speaking at events. If you don’t have any video ready, no worries, record a 5-10 minute video talking about your topic and upload it to a safe place and share the link in the speaker form. 

There is also a Diverse Speaker Support group where selected speakers can get support and feedback from more experienced WordCamp speaker mentors.

Do you need help with your talk?

Here are some additional tips for submitting a speaker proposal:

  • Be clear and concise in your proposal.
  • Highlight your expertise and experience in the topic you are proposing to speak about.
  • Provide a clear outline of your talk, including the key points you will cover.
  • Include any relevant visuals or resources that you will use in your talk.

Underrepresented Speaker Support

We take diversity seriously and encourage members from underrepresented groups to answer our call!
We are happy to announce that we have launched the Underrepresented Speaker Support Initiative in the hope of removing financial barriers for speakers at the same time as this call.

When is the application deadline?

The Call for Speakers will be open until September 30, 2023. Please make sure to send in your application as soon as possible. 

Below are the important dates you need to remember.

  1. July 31, 2023 20:00 – Call for speakers opens
  2. September 30, 2023 23:00 – Application closes 
  3. October 2023 – Speaker selection process
  4. November 2023 – Selected speakers will be contacted
  5. November 2023 – Speakers announcements will start
  6. December 2023 – Speaker announcements completed 

* Timezone is in Taipei, Taiwan time (UTC+8)

What are the next steps?

Once we have received your application, we will review it and let you know if you have been selected. If you are selected, you will receive a formal invitation email that will help if you need to apply for a visa to travel to Taiwan. We are also working on an eVisa program by the Taiwan Ministry of Foreign Affairs for certain countries. Depending on your nationality, you may have different visa requirements to enter Taiwan. For detailed information, please go to meettaiwan.com. 

How many talks can you submit?

We’re a small team and would like to be spending our time creating more value. We understand you might have many ideas and topics to speak about but as we are expecting a big volume of applications, please limit to two,  if you do submit more, we’d only consider the 2 latest entries. Send us your very best talk topics!

Should you buy a ticket?

You can purchase a ticket when ticket sales have opened. If you are selected as a speaker, we will be giving you a complimentary ticket to attend the event. Then you can transfer your purchased ticket to someone else. 

Are you open to be a backup speaker?

During the event we may need to activate a backup speaker due to incidents out of our control. Just in case, let us know if you are willing to be selected as a backup speaker. 

But not to worry, by opting in for Backup Speaker doesn’t necessarily mean you won’t be selected as a main speaker. It just makes the program team easier to know the applicants who were open for the backup speaker, just in case they are not selected as the main speaker.

Visa Letter

If you require a visa to travel to Taiwan in 2024, let us know in your application so that we can send you a letter to make your visa application process smoother. This is not a letter of invitation, but it will state the following:

  • That you are attending the event
  • The dates of the conference
  • The purpose of the conference

For further visa information, we will prepare another post to list the application rules in Taiwan. Please stay tuned.

We are looking forward to receiving your application!

To learn more about the Call for Speakers and to submit your application, please fill out the form.

Thank you!

WordCamp Asia 2024 Program Team

content.rendered:
We are excited to announce that we are opening the initiative we had last year again: the Underrepresented Speaker Support Program.

If you run a business or an individual who is interested in supporting this initiative and helping the speakers, please show your interest by filling out the form.

Apply here

Why are we running this initiative?

The tech industry, which has been a driving force of innovation and change, unfortunately, remains noticeably under-diverse. And over the years, WordPress eco-system has driven many programs to overcome this. But we all have to admit that there is still some room for representation across several key dimensions including gender, race, ethnicity, age, and abilities, among others. The absence of these voices not only undermines the principles of fairness and justice but also hinders the progress and innovation that thrives on diverse perspectives.

At the core of this problem lies the critical need to foster Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging (DEIB). But what does DEIB truly mean?

Diversity is about representation, ensuring that the tech space is filled with individuals from various backgrounds, races, genders, ages, religions, disabilities, and sexual orientations.

Equity means ensuring everyone has access to the same opportunities, recognizing that advantages and barriers exist. It’s about ensuring fairness in procedures, processes, and distribution of resources.

Inclusion means individuals with diverse identities feel valued, leveraged, and welcomed within their working environment.

Belonging is the feeling of security and support when there is a sense of acceptance, inclusion, and identity for a member of a certain group or place. It’s the fundamental human need to connect and be a meaningful part of something greater than oneself. 

For the tech industry to fully harness its innovative potential, understanding and implementing DEIB is crucial. A diverse team brings a wealth of ideas, experiences, and perspectives that can fuel creativity, challenge the status quo, and drive revolutionary solutions. Moreover, an inclusive work culture improves employee satisfaction and retention, fostering a sense of belonging.

Support the Speakers

The Underrepresented Speaker Support Program is designed to address this gap. We are calling on companies to invest in our mission of fostering a more diverse, equitable, and inclusive tech community by sponsoring underrepresented speakers at industry events. This program will help in providing a platform for diverse voices, narratives, and perspectives that are essential in molding the future of technology.

Here’s how you can make a difference:

  • Sponsor a Speaker: Financial support can help overcome the barriers many underrepresented speakers face when it comes to participating in industry events.
  • Provide time to prepare talks: If you have time and capacity, why not have a test-run with the speakers. This could mean, invite them to one of smaller events in advance or have 1-on1 to give feedback.
  • Promote the Cause: Use your company’s reach and influence to advocate for DEIB in the tech industry.

We understand that the road to diversity, equity, and inclusion is a challenging one, and it’s a journey we are committed to taking together. By supporting the Underrepresented Speaker Support Program, you can play an instrumental role in shaping a more inclusive and equitable tech industry.

We urge all companies, big and small, or individuals to take this pledge. Supporting diversity, equity, and inclusion is more than a moral obligation—it’s a strategic imperative for the growth and future of our community. We are excited to work together to give underrepresented voices the platform they deserve.

We want to thank all of you for taking a look at this and hope to work with you all for the bright future.

Apply here

content.rendered:
1. Purpose

WordCamp Asia 2024 believes our community should be truly open for everyone. As such, we are committed to providing a friendly, safe and welcoming environment for all, regardless of gender, sexual orientation, disability, ethnicity, religion, age, caste, social class, preferred operating system, programming language, or text editor, among other identifying characteristics.

This code of conduct outlines our expectations for participant behavior as well as the consequences for unacceptable behavior.

We invite all sponsors, volunteers, speakers, attendees, and other participants to help us realize a safe and positive conference experience for everyone.

2. Open Source Citizenship

A supplemental goal of this code of conduct is to increase open source citizenship by encouraging participants to recognize and strengthen the relationships between what we do and the community at large.

In service of this goal, WordCamp Asia 2024 organizers will be taking nominations for exemplary citizens throughout the event and will recognize select participants after the conference on the website.

If you see someone who is making an extra effort to ensure our community is welcoming, friendly, and encourages all participants to contribute to the fullest extent, we want to know.

3. Expected Behavior

  • Be considerate, respectful, and collaborative.
  • Refrain from demeaning, discriminatory or harassing behavior and speech.
  • Be mindful of your surroundings and of your fellow participants. Alert conference organizers if you notice a dangerous situation or someone in distress.
  • Participate in an authentic and active way. In doing so, you help to create WordCamp Asia 2024 and make it your own.

4. Unacceptable Behavior

Unacceptable behaviors include: intimidating, harassing, abusive, discriminatory, derogatory or demeaning conduct by any attendees of WordCamp Asia 2024 and related events. All WordCamp Asia 2024 venues may be shared with members of the public; please be respectful to all patrons of these locations.

Harassment includes: offensive verbal comments related to gender, sexual orientation, race, religion, disability; inappropriate use of nudity and/or sexual images in public spaces (including presentation slides); deliberate intimidation, stalking or following; harassing photography or recording; sustained disruption of talks or other events; inappropriate physical contact, and unwelcome sexual attention.

5. Consequences Of Unacceptable Behavior

Unacceptable behavior will not be tolerated whether by other attendees, organizers, venue staff, sponsors, or other patrons of WordCamp Asia 2024 venues.

Anyone asked to stop unacceptable behavior is expected to comply immediately.

If a participant engages in unacceptable behavior, the conference organizers may take any action they deem appropriate, up to and including expulsion from the conference without warning or refund.

6. What To Do If You Witness Or Are Subject To Unacceptable Behavior

If you are subject to unacceptable behavior, notice that someone else is being subject to unacceptable behavior, or have any other concerns, please notify a conference organizer as soon as possible.

The WordCamp Asia 2024 team will be available to help participants contact venue security or local law enforcement, to provide escorts, or to otherwise assist those experiencing unacceptable behavior to feel safe for the duration of the conference. Any volunteer can connect you with a conference organizer. You can also come to the special registration desk in the lobby and ask for the organizers.

7. Scope

We expect all conference participants (sponsors, volunteers, speakers, attendees, and other guests) to abide by this code of conduct at all conference venues and conference-related social events.

8. Contact Information

Contact the organizers through this site’s contact form

9. License And Attribution

This Code of Conduct is a direct swipe from the awesome work of Open Source Bridge, but with our event information substituted. The original is available at Open Source Bridge 2018 [archived] and is released under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike license.

Statement about Socials or Supplemental Events (where applicable)

Social and supplemental events are intended to provide networking and additional educational opportunities, as well as an opportunity to unwind after a full WordCamp. They should also be places where attendees can feel safe and secure.

We want you to enjoy yourself at these events, and we want you to do so safely. If you experience a Code of Conduct violation, see a violation, are concerned about the well-being, safety or behavior of another attendee, or have a general question (we understand that violations are not always obvious!) contact us immediately by notifying a WordCamp organizer or emailing report@wordcamp.org. For in-person events, if you need help or are unable to comfortably or safely remove yourself from a situation you do not want to be in, organizers will prioritize assisting you immediately and discretely. Some examples are: not feeling well; your transportation arrangements fall through; you are intoxicated, you are alone or with someone you do not trust, you are overwhelmed, you have experienced or witnessed a Code of Conduct violation. Please ask any nearby event volunteer or organizer to help you.

• Ahmed Kabir Chaion

    Ahmed Kabir Chaion works as a Project Manager at Zone7. He also serves as one of the Team Reps for Making WordPress Polyglots and the former Team Rep for Making WordPress Global Design. He’s also one of the co-organizers of the Dhaka WordPress Meetup. As a self-sponsored contributor from Bangladesh, Ahmed tries to give back as much as possible through his contributions to the WordPress project, WordPress meetups, WordCamps, and the community.

    🇧🇩 Bangladesh / @chaion07 / https://au.linkedin.com/in/chaion07

    Team: Contributor Day

  • Andy Saw

    Boasting 22 years in the hosting industry, Andy carved a legacy as the COO of Exabytes before venturing into new horizons. Acclaimed for his prowess in leadership and operational excellence, he’s also an active luminary in the WordPress sphere. Since 2017, he’s co-led local Meetups, orchestrated WordCamp Kuala Lumpur, and been instrumental in organizing WordCamp Asia for both 2023 and 2024. As he explores the next steps, his passion and dedication to the WordCamp community remain strong.

She is familiar with WordPress since 2019. She volunteered at WordCamp Sylhet 2023 as an Interviewer, attended WordCamp Asia 2023, and spoke at WordCamp Kathmandu 2023. Apart from her working hours, she loves to explore nature and meet different types of people around the globe.

    🇧🇩 Bangladesh / @anjum_prema

    Arvind possesses a deep understanding of the ever-evolving market demands within the WordPress sphere. This knowledge allows him to craft hosting packages that are tailored to meet the specific needs of today’s website owners and businesses. His commitment to staying at the forefront of industry trends ensures that MadPopo remains a leading player in the WordPress hosting market.

    🇮🇳 India / @ArvindBaraskar / https://madpopo.com

With over a decade of experience, Blake has been sharing their travel stories on a blog.

    🇹🇼 Taiwan/ @blakecheng_tw / bdatin.com

Never stop exploring is what we say, thus we’re always searching for creative and friendly solutions for our clients. Projects and work diverse endlessly from online classes to corporate website all the way to Web3 universe, nothing can stop the curiosity.

Inspired by the vibrant spirit at WordCamp Asia 2023, she immediately joined the Website team for WordCamp Taiwan 2023. Also, she has an unexplainable fondness for Winnie the Pooh!

This connection was made possible through Devin, a WP friend with whom I had previously worked to run climate change campaigns. Actually, I only use WordPress only to share about my personal experiences, which since 2012!! At the moment, my aspiration is to become someone who is most useful to others. Also, I am working to achieve my career in academia. Wish me luck!

    🇹🇼 Taiwan / @epriwp / https://tw.linkedin.com/in/epri-wahyu

    🇹🇼 Taiwan / @eric032410 / https://bonnie22.com/

Running a casual blog ReadJazz about movies and jazz with podcasts sometimes.

    🇹🇼 Taiwan/ https://hend.design/

    Team: Communications, Local

  • Holly Reid

    Holly is an avid traveller, reader and cullinary enthusiast. For the past ten years, she’s worked with large-scale artistic and literary events across Southeast Asia and Australia. She currently works for the parent company behind WordPress.com, Automattic, where she develops and delivers learning intiatives for the 2000-strong remote business.

    🇮🇩 Bali

    Team: Communications

  • Hsin Hui Lin

    Graphic designer, with experience in event branding and packaging design as well.I came into contact with WordPress because I was building my own portfolio website.Participated in the preparation of previous WordCamp Taiwan as a volunteer.Looking forward to meeting people from different fields at the event.

    🇹🇼 Taiwan / https://www.hsinhui.com

JC also served as one of the global leads for WordCamp Asia 2023, showcasing her commitment to the WordPress community and web development.

    🇵🇭 Philippines / @jpalmes / https://khleomix.com/

    Team: Contributor Day (Lead)

  • Jon Ang

    Jon is the Documentation Lead of WordPress and a component maintainer for the Core team. He also regularly speaks at events and helps with new local WordCamps in the region.

    On the professional side – he’s the Director of Sales for Human Made – an award-winning Enterprise WordPress agency creating the digital success of the likes of TechCrunch, NewsUK, RedBull and Capgemini.

    🇸🇬 Singapore / @kenshino

    Team: Sponsor

    She has been a part of the organizing teams of WordCamps, Meetups, and do_action events in Japan. She also works on diversity speaker training.
    She is currently contributing to the WordPress project as one of the 2023 Make WordPress Community Team Reps.

    🇯🇵 Japan / nukaga / https://nukagajunko.com/

    Team: Design (Lead)

    Liew is a WordPress professional and certified AWS Cloud Practitioner with a deep understanding of the WordPress platform.   • Mayo Moriyama

    🇯🇵Japan & 🇲🇾Malaysia / @mayukojpn / mayuko.me

    Team: Volunteer / AV

  • Meher Bala

    Meher is the COO at KDC, a Codeable Expert and a front-end developer. She was a part of Marcoms for WordPress 6.3 and 6.4. She also contributes to different teams, co-organisers WordCamp Mumbai and India and speaking at multiple WordCamps.

    🇮🇳 India / @meherbala / https://meherbala.com

    Team: Program

  • Mike Chen

    I’m Mike! My expertise lies in web visual design, brand design, and UI design. I often use WordPress to build websites. I actively participate in the WordPress community every month and share content related to designing and building with WordPress.

    🇹🇼 Taiwan

    Team: Local

  • mimi

In 2019, she began hosting a personal study group on the Gutenberg Project, which meets twice a month. Then in 2021, she started co-organizing monthly small study sessions about Design and WordPress.

    🇯🇵 Japan/ @miminari/ https://blog.photosynthesic.jp/

Her lifelong journey to success has been significantly shaped by WordPress and its endless possibilities.

    🇯🇵 Japan / @namuaminyan

    Team: Sponsor

    🇹🇭 Thailand / @l3eaver / pantip.ws

    🇵🇭 Philippines / @oneal / https://trooperdad.com/

    Team: Communications

    🇹🇼 Taiwan

    Team: Communications

    Shusei is a creative director based in Tokyo, Japan. Having the background of being a web-designer and engineer, currently focuses on creating brand/corporate/visual contents for clients with project management, photos, videos and creative strategy. Had been involved with the WordPress community since 2018 and had been contributing to the project with various ways locally and globally.

    🇯🇵 Japan / @shuseitoda / https://shuseitoda.com

    Team: Program (Lead)

  • Spencer Ravago

    Spencer is a designer with a background in branding and UX design. He is based in Iloilo, Philippines where he is active in the WordPress community. He has been part of the organizing team of WordCamp Iloilo since it’s inception.

    🇵🇭 Philippines / @spencerravago / https://spencerravago.com

    Team: Design

  • Surendra Shrestha

    Surendra, the CEO and founder of Rigorous Web and Aarambha Themes, boasts a decade of WordPress expertise through Codeable. He is an active WordPress advocate, organizing, volunteering, and speaking at WordCamps. Notably, he recently led WordCamp Kathmandu 2023 and contributed to the Marketing Team at WCAsia 2023, showcasing his strong commitment to the global WordPress community.

    🇳🇵 Nepal / @nepsure / https://ersurendra.com/

  • Susumu Seino

    Susumu Seino is the founder of aniuma OÜ based in Estonia. He has been a part of the organizing teams of WordCamps, Meetups in Japan. He went on to attend more than 30 WordCamps, mostly in Asia and Europe.He was the lead organizer for WordCamp Tokyo in 2014 and 2015.

    🇯🇵 Japan / @susumu1127 / https://susu.mu

    Team: Volunteer / AV

  • Toru Miki

    Toru is Web Developer/Engineer, currently working at Tokyo based company Tarosky. At Tarosky, we engineer mid-to-enterprise scale WordPress websites, where my current focus is around server-side development, and exploring the way to improve our developer experience, teamwork, and output quality. User of WordPress since 2005, Toru has helped Japanese WordPress community in translations, organizing meetups and WordCamps. Frequent speaker, sometimes podcast emcee, and make code contributions every now and then.

    🇯🇵 Japan / @waviaei / https://torumiki.com

    Team: Contributor Day

  • Vachan Kudmule

    Vachan’s motto is “everything can and must be designed”. Self learning & exploring new ideas keeps him motivated. He is part of WordPress & WooCommerce Mumbai Communities. Speaker at multiple WordCamps, led do_action Mumbai 2019. Developed many custom plugins on WooCommerce for clients via his agency KDC.in

    🇮🇳 India / @DezineNinja / https://dezine.ninja

  • Vanita Nandakumar

    Has worked a myriad of roles in the agency world from client services, content, design, digital marketing, and operations in industries like fire safety, film/media, medical, and now WordPress. Actively contributing since 2019 to the community, through the Polyglots team, for Tamil, Hindi, Telugu, Kannada, Punjabi, Marathi, Malayalam and Bengali translations. She works at Human Made as their Agency Operations Manager. She is also an organiser for her local chapter; WordPress Tamil Nadu.

    Yuli Yang is an owner of a small agency dejavu.studio and a devoted mother of two. She loves her work so much that it doesn’t feel like a job. She has led and currently mentoring WordCamps and WordPress meetups in Taiwan. In her free time, she enjoys gaming and planning fun activities with her kids.

    🇹🇼 Taiwan / @YuliYang_Ching / https://yuliyang.com/

We extend our sincere gratitude to our esteemed sponsors for their unwavering support in making WordCamp Asia 2024 an unforgettable experience. Without their commitment and generosity, this event would not be possible, and we are truly grateful for their partnership.

Get to Know Our Sponsors

Click on the logos below to explore dedicated profiles that offer deeper insights into each sponsor’s contributions to the WordPress community. Learn more about their endeavors, services, and commitment to empowering the WordPress ecosystem. These profiles serve as a window into the valuable role our sponsors play in shaping the WordPress landscape.

Discover More at the Event

Be sure to visit our sponsors’ booths throughout the venue, where you can engage with their teams, explore exciting offerings, and discover the latest innovations in the WordPress sphere. We hope all attendees take advantage of this opportunity to connect with these forward-thinking companies and learn how they’re contributing to the growth and success of WordPress.
